 L. THE ENERGY SECTOR 1.1 The Kvrgyz Republic (KR) is a small, land-locked country with a population of 4.5 million and an estimated per capita income of US$ 830 (1993). The energy sector is relatively large and has an important role in the economy. The country has abundant low-cost hydropower resources which have been partially developed, small oil and gas production, and a collapsing coal industry. Under the Former Soviet Union (FSU), the country evolved from an agriculturally-based economy to one with a significant industrial base which accounted just prior to independence for about 40% of GDP. The economy was also highly integrated with the rest of the FSU. A net importer of coal, petroleum products and natural gas, the KR is a net exporter of electricity to neighboring republics (mainly Kazakstan). Since independence, energy import prices have risen sharply toward international levels while economic activity in the region has declined. The result has been a deterioration in the terms of trade for the KR, with net energy imports contributing about US$110 million to the annual trade imbalance (estimated at US$119 million in 1994).' This occured despite a halving of energy consumption due to sharp declines in industrial and agricultural production during 1991-94. At the same time, household consumption of electricity and natural gas, which are highly subsidized, rose rapidly. 1.2 The Government of the KR (GOK or the Government) recognizes the energy sector's importance in economic recovery and growth as the country makes the transition toward a market economy, and its policies call for increased efficiency in energy production and use, reduced government involvement in the sector and efforts to attract private sector involvement in developing domestic resources. The Bank carried out a review of the overall energy sector in 1994, the findings of which are summarized below.2 The proposed Power and District Heating Rehabilitation Project is consistent with GOK's priorities and the findings of the Bank's review, and will help implement key actions to improve the power and heat sector's performance. A. ENERGY RESOURCES, PRODUCTION AND TRADE 1.3 KR's energy resources comprise: oil and natural gas, coal, wood and other biomass, and hydropower. Remaining recoverable oil and gas reserves in the Fergana Valley are estimated at 12 million tons and 6.5 billion cubic meters. Production of most of the remaining oil reserves will require enhanced recovery methods; further, since there was limited exploration for oil and gas in the KR during the Soviet era, several potentially promising oil provinces (e.g., East Chui and Alai Valleys) have yet to be systematically explored. Proven coal reserves (hard and brown coal) are about 1.2 billion tons, of which 650 million tons have been prepared for mining; however, commercial exploitation of these reserves is severely handicapped by the mountainous terrain and consequent difficult access to the deposits, as well as the location of potential markets. The standing stock of wood in the forest estates is estimated at 23 million cubic meters and is threatened by illegal cutting for wood fuel. Dung is commonly used as fuel, and efforts are being made to promote solar and micro-hydro, but the economic context is not favorable. KR's hydropower potential is estimated at 26,000 MW, of which about 2,870 MW has been developed on the lower Naryn River. Production in a normal hydrological year is 10,000 GWh; In 1995, with the decrease in power exports and the increase of the price of gas and petroleum products, net energy imports are estimated at US$170 million and the annual trade imbalance at US$227million. 2 Kyrgyz Republic: Energy Sector Review (Report No. 14036-KG of May 15, 1995).
 2 The Energy Sector however, as there is a need to store water for summer irrigation in downstream countries of Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan, most of the energy is produced in summer when it is least needed. Development of a further 2,260 MW upstream, which could be constructed at relatively low unit cost and operated without irrigation constraints, was initiated before the break-up of the FSU but has been suspended due to the lack of financing. 1.4 Energy balances for 1991 and 1994, in physical units and tons of oil equivalent (toe), are given in Annex 1.1. Domestic energy production (1.6 million toe in 1994, down from 2.7 million toe in 1991) accounted for about 40% of the country's primary energy supply (including exports) in 1994. Primary production of electricity (hydropower) has remained stable during 1991-94, while coal production has collapsed as a result of market-based pricing of coal, so that the closing of at least some mines is unavoidable; oil and gas production has continued at low (and declining) levels. The cost of producing and transporting domestic coal makes it uncompetitive with alternative energy sources in the KR including imported coal and natural gas; in addition, electricity prices are highly subsidized and the Government has deliberately encouraged consumers to switch to increased electrical use for heating and cooking. Thernal power generation and district heating at the two combined-heat-and-power plants in Bishkek (609 MW) and Osh (50 MW) has halved during 1991-94. 1.5 The Kyrgyz Republic depends on its Central Asian neighbors and Russia for about 60% of its primary energy supply as well as for its exports. Energy imports fell sharply from 5.5 million toe in 1991 to about 2.2 million toe in 1994. Imports of petroleum products and natural gas have declined sharply since 1991 due to falling domestic demand. Imports of coal have also halved. KR is a net exporter of electricity due to its hydropower resources but in the absence of long term export contracts, the quantities exported fluctuate and are uncertain. 1.6 Key factors affecting the country's future energy production and trade include: (a) the rate of economic recovery in the Kyrgyz Republic and neighboring republics; (b) trading arrangements negotiated with neighboring countries; and (c) KR's ability to attract private sector participation and financing to enhance production of domestic coal, oil, natural gas and hydropower resources. 1994 has been a year of stabilization for the Kyrgyz economy, and there is some optimism that a gradual recovery will begin in 1995-96. Regional energy trade will continue to be critically important for the country; negotiating long-term contracts with equitable terms of trade and working out appropriate payment systems are a high priority for the Government. In the future, the energy sector should be increasingly self-financing rather than a drain on the national budget and balance of payments. The present under-utilization of the sector's supply capacity provides an important opportunity for the Government to restructure and rehabilitate the sector without being under intense pressure to add new capacity. This will be critical to achieving greater private sector involvement in the sector and to sustaining present production levels let alone increasing them as the economy begins to recover. B. ENERGY CONSUMPrION 1.7 Primary energy consumption in the Kyrgyz Republic in 1991 was 6.8 million toe, or 1,510 kilograms oil equivalent (koe) per capita. While low when compared to other FSU countries, it was relatively high compared to middle-income countries in Asia and Latin America. By 1994, consumption had more than halved, reaching 3.3 million toe and 740 koe per capita. This paralleled the decline in the economy's real output (GDP).
 The Energy Sector 3 1.8 On a sectoral basis, household consumption of energy declined by 36% during 1991-94, while consumption by industry, agriculture and transport fell to 33 %-45 % of their pre- independence levels. Household and industrial shares of final energy consumption also changed drastically, with households now accounting for 39% and industry 32% (shares in 1991 were 27% and 41%, respectively). With final consumption of petroleum products, coal, district heating and gas declining by 30% -76%, electricity remaining more or less constant, and firewood and dung increasing, the resource mix has also changed. In the case of electricity, household consumption more than doubled during 1991-94 while industrial and agricultural consumption fell by 23%-43%. This reflects the increased use of electricity for cooking and heating, and has resulted in overloading of the transmission and distribution systems. Total energy consumption in the Kyrgyz Republic is unlikely to fall further, although the trends in interfuel substitution may continue in the near term as coal loses more ground to electricity. Once economic growth recovers, energy consumption will inevitably rise but at a slower rate than GDP as energy efficiency measures begin to have some impact. The breakdown of primary energy supply by fuel type and sectoral distribution of final energy consumption for 1991 and 1994 are given in Annex 1. 2. C. ENERGY PRICING 1.9 Significant adjustments have been made in energy prices in the Kyrgyz Republic since independence although distortions still exist in relative prices; recent trends in Kyrgyz energy prices are given in Annex 1.3. Prices of coal, petroleum products and natural gas for industry are now largely at international levels, with import prices passed through to consumers. Consistent with GOK's general policy of eliminating distortions caused by a command economy and reducing the state's role, prices of coal and petroleum products have been fully liberalized. However, prices of the network energies--electricity, district heating and natural gas for households--remain under government control and have been kept artificially low and the structure heavily biased in favor of household consumers. This has led to distorted energy consumption patterns, inequitable prices for some consumers and a deteriorating financial condition for the utilities. 1.10 The Government has agreed, as part of its 1994-97 stabilization program with the IMF, to raise energy utility tariffs to households to achieve cost recovery. Further increases will be necessary to ensure the power and gas utilities' abilities to make needed investments to rehabilitate and expand their facilities as well as achieve a reasonable return on their assets. At the same time, GOK will need to protect low-income consumers impacted by rising energy prices, perhaps through provision of cash subsidies, fuel coupons or lifeline tariffs; increased taxes on petroleum products (e.g., gasoline) could be used to fund such assistance. D. ENERGY CONSERVATION AND EFFICIENCY IROVEMENTS 1.11 There are major inefficiencies inherited from the FSU and there remains scope for efficiency improvements on both the supply and end-use sides. On the supply side, for example, there is potential for loss reduction in electricity distribution and district heating, both of which will be addressed under the proposed Project through rehabilitation and upgrading of the present systems in selected areas. On the end-use side, economic pricing, proper metering and enforced payment collection together with promotion of energy conservation and consumer education could lead to improved energy efficiency. Considerable progress has been made in terms of
 4 The Energy Sector pricing as noted above, and the various energy agencies are initiating procedures for improved collections; these issues would also be addressed in the case of electricity and district heating under the proposed Project. The household survey carried out in connection with the Bank's Energy Sector Review in mid-1994 found a high level of ignorance about energy saving opportunities which will need to be addressed through consumer education. Under EU-TACIS assistance, energy audits of twelve selected industries and twelve commercial and apartment buildings were carried out and provided recommendations for energy savings. During negotiations, the Government agreed to implement, by December 31, 1997, the recommendations for energy conservation and efficiency, including use of high-efficiency household appliances and introduction of regulatory measures to improve energy efficiency in existing and newt, buildings. E. ORGANIZATION OF THE ENERGY SECTOR 1.12 The energy sector in the Kyrgyz Republic comprises six state-owned enterprises responsible for electricity and district heating (KNEHC - Kyrgyz National Energy Holding Company), coal mining (Kyrgyzk-umyr) and distribution (Krygyztopsnab), petroleum exploration and production (Kyrgyzneft), petroleum products distribution (Kyrgyzmunaizat) and natural gas distribution (Krygyzgas), and one state committee, Goskomgeologia, responsible for mineral resources (including petroleum) exploration on a national level. Central coordination of the sector is diffuse: (a) KNEHC and Goskomgeologia report to a Deputy Prime Minister; and (b) the remaining energy enterprises come under the aegis of the Ministry of Industry and Trade (Annex 1. 4). The Anti-Monopoly Commission under the Ministry of Economy sets utility tariffs based on submissions from the power and gas utilities. The State Property Fund is also involved in managing government holdings in state enterprises and formulation of privatization plans. With the relaxation of the Government's involvement in the energy sector, the domestic private sector has ventured into trading and distributing petroleum products, LPG and coal, and coal mining. 1.13 For now, public sector enterprises remain responsible for the bulk of activities in the sector. Most of the enterprises (except Kyrgyzneft) have been cut off from the national budget, and the Government has little or no control over their operations while management has considerable powers. Governance and financial management of the enterprises, however, are very weak, and in many respects, they remain akin to government departments (e.g., in terms of adopting social policies) instead of operating on a commercial basis. Prior to independence, most decisions were taken by the central authorities in the FSIJ. so that local expertise in policy and planning matters is limited. There is a need for a central focal point, in the form of a relatively small energy cell/unit within the Government. for formulation and oversight of general energy policies on GOK's behalf. Moreover, the legal and regulatory framework needed to underpin GOK's plan to reduce its involvement in the sector and bring in greater private sector participation has yet to be put in place. Assistance is being provided in this regard for inter alia preparing and implementing an overall energy law and regulatory framework, electricity law, petroleum law and model contract, and modifying the subsurface resources law. Assistance will also be needed in restructuring, commercializing and ultimately privatizing those energy enterprises which are viable and in closing those which are not. Under the proposed Project, assistance will be provided for developing an overall strategy for restructuring the power and heat sector and beginning to implement it through restructuring and commercialization of KNEHC; this will build on earlier assistance from EU-TACIS and EBRD.
 The Energy Sector 5 F. ENERGY AND THE ENVIRONMENT 1.14 A national environmental action plan (NEAP) for the Kyrgyz Republic has been prepared with the assistance of the Bank3. The priority areas for the energy sector include watershed management (affecting hydropower resources) and dam safety, emissions from coal-fired thermal plants and boilers, and coal mining operations (including pending closures of uneconomic mines). Attention to reviewing and developing as necessary environmental standards and regulations, strengthening of monitoring and enforcement capabilities, and developing the capacity to carry out environmental impact assessments and efficiency/environmental audits are being given priority under the NEAP definition of environmental liability for past pollution and establishing legal guidelines for settling liability conflicts are also important complements to the country's privatization process. The proposed project will improve efficiency in production and use of electricity and district heating (including reducing water usage), and will upgrade instrumentation and control equipment and install emission monitoring devices at the Bishkek thermal plant (609 MW). G. SECTOR DEVELOPNIENT STRATEGY 1.15 The year 1994 was a milestone in the Kyrgyz Republic's transition to a market economy. GOK's commitment to reform was sustained through difficult economic circumstances. The country is at a critical juncture, whereby the Government now needs to foster actual changes in institutions, economic agents and the manner in which they interact. GOK's key medium-term goals in this process are to: (a) consolidate and deepen the stabilization and structural reform program; (b) lay the legal, institutional and regulatory framework for renewed growth; and (c) maintain an adequate social safety net and alleviate rural poverty. Improving energy sector efficiency is an important element of this broader reform program, and actions needed to achieve this parallel those required for the overall economy. 1.16 The main focus of GOK's post-independence energy policy has been: (a) increased reliance on indigenous energy supplies to reduce imports; (b) restructuring of energy entities to increase their autonomy and self-sufficiency; (c) attracting private sector participation to improve efficiency and mobilize financing; (d) establishment of the legal and regulatory framework to facilitate the above; (e) introduction of energy pricing policy to encourage efficient use and sustain sector development but also take account of social objectives; (f) promotion of energy conservation and use of renewable energy; and (g) modernization and development of the sector's production capacity. The Government has articulated these goals/objectives in both its Energy Program of Kyrgyzstan (1992) and Energy Concept Paper (1995) and, with assistance from donors, is proceeding to act on them. 1.17 As indicated above, the energy sector has undergone many changes since 1991 and some progress has been made in adjusting its operations toward a more market-based approach. As in the case of the country's overall economic reform program, however, further actions are still required in a number of areas. Key among these are: (a) adjusting network energy prices and improving collections; (b) restructuring, commercializing and ultimately privatizing energy enterprises which are viable and closing those which are not; and (c) preparing the necessary 3 Krgyz Republic - National Environmenital Action Plan Report No. 13990-KG, May 2, 1995.
 6 The Energy Sector legal, regulatory and institutional framework for the sector's development. These actions are outlined in more detail in the Bank's Energy Sector Review and have been discussed with the Government. GOK is in general agreement with the recommendations and intends to implement them. As for physical investments in the energy sector, the priority for the near-medium term will be rehabilitation and upgrading of existing facilities, measures to improve energy efficiency both in supply and use, and completion of projects which have been stopped due to lack of funds provided a firm market is in place for the project's output. With plans to turn many activities in the sector over to the private sector, GOK's main investment concerns will be the energy utilities since the private sector will make its own investment decisions. 1.18 Donor Assistance. A number of agencies (ADB, EBRD, European Union-TACIS, Islamic Development Bank and World Bank) and bilateral donors (Austria, Denmark, Germany, Japan, Norway, Switzerland and U.S.) have been involved in providing assistance to the Kyrgyz energy sector over the last three years. The proposed Project, which is expected to be co-financed by ADB, Danida, Nordic Development Fund and the Swiss Government, will assist GOK and KNEHC to address policy, price and management issues in the power and heat sector as well as to rehabilitate and upgrade existing facilities, hence improving efficiency and reliability of supply. The Bank is also providing assistance to the upstream petroleum sector through execution of (a) a Norwegian Trust Fund grant supporting preparation of a petroleum law, model contract and fiscal regime; and (b) a Japanese PHRD grant supporting review and assessment of existing geological/geophysical data. If warranted, the proposed project will assist GOK carry out a promotion of the country's petroleum prospects, to the international oil industry.
 II. THE POWER AND HEAT SECTOR A. PAST POWER AND HEAT CONSUMPTION AND SUPPLY 2.1 Power Market. Domestic demand for power and heat have remained stagnant or declined over 1991-94, while the structure of the markets have changed significantly. In the case of power, the share of residential consumers increased from 15% to 40% during 1990-94, while that of industrial consumers declined from 45% to 26%. The near tripling of residential consumption is explained by the low price for electricity, particularly relative to alternative heating and cooking fuels. Further, the government promoted the use of electricity (i.e., hydropower) to substitute for imported fuels including, coal, fuel oil and natural gas'. The decline in industrial as well as agricultural consumption of electricity is explained by the economic difficulties confronting the Kyrgyz Republic. 2.2 As a result, trends in domestic electricity sales in recent years have been as follows: Power Market in Kyrgyz Republic (GWh) AVG ANNUAL GROwrH 1990 1991 1992 1993 1994 1990-94 INDUSTRY 3,468 3,509 2,974 2,464 2,031 -12% AGRUCULTLTRE 1,913 1,986 1,872 1,846 1,526 -5% RESIDENTIAL 1,111 1,455 1,951 2,455 3,159 30% OTHER 1,152 1.179 1.314 1.220 1.114 -1% TOTAL 7,644 8.129 811 7985 830 1% Bishkek and the surrounding Chu valley accounted for 41 % of electricity sales in 1994, followed by the Osh (24%) and Dzhallal Abad (13%) districts. The country is effectively fully electrified; KNEHC has just under 975,000 connections, of which 950,000 are residential consumers. The average monthly consumption of residential consumers is fairly high (301 kWh in urban areas, 259 kWh in rural areas) and is on the rise, which can be explained mostly by the increasing use of electricity for heating.2 Further details on the domestic power market are in Annex 2.1. 2.3 Regarding export sales, KNEHC's power system is interconnected to the Central Asian Integrated System (CAIS), which also includes Kazakstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. In 1993, small-scale exports to China were initiated. 2.4 Southern Kazakstan is presently the main export market for KNEHC electricity surpluses. Unlike most power export contracts which are of a long-term nature, the agreement with Kazakstan is renewed on an annual (or even more frequent) basis. Exports declined from about 4,000 GWh in 1990-91 to 1,000 GWh in 1993, due to the general economic decline in the region; in 1994, they increased to 2,500 GWh due in part to an unusually wet year, and are expected to be 1,500 GWh in 1995. In 1995, however, there was no agreement until mid-year (and thus no exports) which underscores the importance of concluding long term export arrangements, particularly given KR's endowment with hydropower resources and its neighbor's dependence on fossil fuels. 2.5 Heat Market. KNEHC supplies district heating (heat, hot water and process steam) to consumers in Bishkek, Karakol, Karakul, Kyzil Kiya and Osh. District heating sales in recent years have been as follows: HEAT MARKET IN KYRGYZ REPUBLIC (1000 Gcal) AVG ANNuAL GROWTH 1990 1991 1992 1993 1994 1990-94 INDUSTRY 2,097 2,100 1,647 904 498 -30% AGRICULTURE 197 194 135 87 96 -16% RESIDENTiAL 1,894 1,843 1,876 2,216 1,502 -6% OTHER 1I210 1 286 1,139 760 601 -16% TOTAL 5398 5,423 4.797 3,967 2698 -16% 2.6 The overall volume of district heating sales in 1994 is thus about half that of 1990-91. While industrial consumption has fallen because of the economic situation, the main reason for the overall decline is rationing by KNEHC, including ceasing supply of hot water during the warm season, to conserve imported fuels. Increased use of electrical heaters and boilers is offsetting the reduced temperatures at which heat is supplied in the winter. In 1994, 56% of the heat was sold to residential consumers, 22% to public administration/other (schools, hospitals, etc.), 18% to industry and the balance to agriculture (mostly greenhouses). Bishkek alone, with 370,000 consumers, accounts for about 80% of the district heating market. Recently completed energy audits show that per capita consumption of heat and hot water in the Kyrgyz Republic are high relative to that in comparable climates in Western Europe; this can be attributed to lack of temperature control and metering at the user end, poor building insulation and low district heating tariffs.
 The Power and Heat Sector 9 B. EXISTING FACILITIES 2.7 Electricity. KNEHC operates 20 power plants with a total installed capacity of 3,532 MW, including 18 hydropower plants (2,873 MW) and two combined heat-and-power (CHP) plants in the cities of Bishkek (609 MW) and Osh (50 MW). Power balances for recent years are as follows: Power Generation, Sales and Losses (GWH) 1990 1991 1992 1993 1994 GENERATION 13,155 13,972 11,880 11,169 12,860 -THERMAL 4,202 3,914 2,602 2,090 1,140 -HYDRO 8,953 10,058 9,278 9,079 11,720 NET SALES 11,622 12,421 10,288 9,009 10,336 -DOMESTIC 7,644 8,129 8,112 7,985 7,830 -EXPORTS (NET) 3,978 4,293 2,176 1,023 2,505 OWN USE 498 487 405 354 360 LossEs 1,035 1,064 1,187 1,806 2,164 PEA.K DEMAND(MW) 1,590 1,751 1,805 1,972 2,173 2.8 In 1994, KNEHC generated 12,860 GWh, of which 1,140 GWh were from thermal plants and 11,720 GWh from hydro plants. Net sales including exports were 10,336 GWh and the peak load 2,173 MW. System losses have more than doubled since 1990-91, reaching 17% of gross generation in 1994. The peak load has also increased significantly, despite net sales declining. Both factors suggest increasingly inefficient operation of the system and can be attributed at least in part to the rapid growth in residential sales, particularly the increased use of electricity for heating. Overloading of the transmission and distribution networks and insufficient maintenance have contributed to the increased system losses; the low price and lack of incentives to use electricity off-peak (e.g., seasonal and time-of-day tariffs) have contributed to the growth in peak demand. While the system is not presently constrained by generating capacity due to the economic situation, it is affected by limitations in the transmission and distribution network capacity. 2.9 Hydroelectric Generation Facilities. The bulk of installed hydro capacity is located on the Naryn cascade. The program to develop the lower Naryn river began in the 1960s with the construction of Uch-Kurgan, (4 x 45 MW), which has now accumulated over 33 years of operation and is in need of refurbishing. In the 1970s, the Toktogul reservoir, with 16 billion cubic meters water storage (about one and a half times the annual inflow) and 1,200 MW (4 x 300 MW) installed capacity, was constructed upstream to provide regulation of the Naryn river together with the Kurpsai plant, (4 x 200 MW). Subsequently, two projects were developed in the cascade, Tashkumir (3 x 150 MW) and Shamaldisai (3 x 80 MW); construction of neither project is fully complete. At Tashkumir, the dam needs to be raised to provide adequate head

Further details on KNEHC's generating facilities are in Annex 2.2. 2.10 Thermal Generation Facilities. Bishkek and Osh are supplied with electricity and heat by the country's only two thermal CHP stations. Bishkek TES 1 consists of 10 steam turbines and 24 boilers with the capability of burning coal, fuel oil and natural gas. Its nominal capacity is only 558 MW (instead of 609 MW) and 1,360 MJ/s (1,157 Gcal/hr) when generating both heat and electricity. An additional 660 Gcal/hr could be produced from heat-only boilers (HOBs) and pre-heat boilers. The Bishkek plant presently burns mainly Kazak coal under barter arrangement. Osh TES 1 consists of two 25 MW steam turbines and three boilers with a combined capacity of 375 tons per hour. The boilers at Osh are designed to burn only fuel oil and natural gas. Further details on installed generating capacity are in Annex 2.2. 2.11 Bishkek TES 1 plays a key role in the supply of power to the northern region and of heat to Bishkek. However, out of its 24 boilers, 13 have accumulated over 100,000 hours of operation; among the remaining boilers seven have been selected for refurbishment and life extension. Also four out of the ten turbines have accumulated over 200,000 hours of operation and need to be monitored regularly with non-destructive metallurgical tests. Construction of a new 90 MW turbine, which is on site, could not be completed because of the equipment was only partially delivered. There are also problems with obsolescence and wear on plant auxiliary systems, such as coal handling, compressed air, water make up, air pollution control, ash storage, and instrumentation and control which affect plant availability, efficiency and environmental impacts. The review of alternatives for the supply of power to the system and heat to the city of Bishkek has concluded that refurbishment of Bishkek TES 1 is the least cost alternative. 2.12 Transmission and Distribution Facilities. At the end of 1994, the transmission system in the Kyrgyz Republic consisted of 545 km of 500-kV lines, 1,150 km of 220-kV, and 4,440 km of 110-kV lines. The distribution system consisted of 4,310 km of 35-kV lines, 39,380 km of 10-kV and 6-kV lines, and 29,350 km of 0.4-kV lines. There are a total of 498 step-down transformer substations (500, 220, 110 and 35-kV) with a total capacity of 8,620 MVA. Further details on KNEHC's transmission and distribution facilities are in Annex 2.3. The Kyrgyz transmission system is part of the Central Asian Integrated System integrated at 500 kV and 220 kV (see map IBRD 27 671). The northern part of the Kyrgyz Republic is connected to the south, where the bulk of hydro generation is located, through a 500-kV transmission line crossing the mountain ranges at 3,500 meters altitude and through a second 500-kV line at lower altitude via Uzbekistan and Kazakstan. 2.13 The 500-kV and 220-kV transmission lines appear sufficient to meet demand requirements up to the year 2000. However, the change in the structure of the demand away from high- voltage industrial consumers to low-voltage household and commercial consumers has caused serious overloading of the 1 10-kV and 35-kV systems, 220/1 10-kV and 110/35-kV transformers and the distribution systems of major load centers. These facilities were already in poor condition due to lack of maintenance. The results are excessive losses, voltage drops and fluctuations, outages, and damage to transformers, cables, meters and other equipment. During the 1993-94 winter, 2,261 of KNEHC's 17,000 distribution substations were found to be overloaded; the situation in winter 1994-95 was worse, leading to voltage drop and widespread interruption of supply. In the Issyk-Kul and Naryn regions the voltage drop in winter are
 The Power and Heat Sector 11 beyond what would be tolerable. System losses were 17% of net generation in 1994 and are estimated at 20% in 1995, while in an efficient power system they should be less than 10%. Reduction of these losses will require sizable investments in rehabilitation upgrading and reinforcement of the transmission and distribution network. 2.14 District Heating. The Kyrgyz Republic has district heating (DH) systems in Bishkek, Karakol, Karakul, Kyzil Kiya and Osh. Supply of heat in Bishkek and Osh is mainly from combined heat-and-power plants while Karakol, Karakul and Kyzil Kiya are supplied from heat- only boilers, some of which have recently been replaced by electrical boilers. The overall DH network consists of about 460 km of hot water and steam lines, the bulk of which are in Bishkek (about 331 km of hot water lines and 57 km of steam lines). SECTOR PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT 2.17 Since the Kyrgyz economy is in transition between two different economic systems, long-run forecasts of electricity and heat demand are not reliable. This is compounded by the uncertainty regarding the impact of tariff increases and enforcement of strong billing and collection measures to reduce non-technical losses. Consumption of power and heat in the productive sectors of the Kyrgyz Republic has dropped sharply since 1991, concurrently with the drop in GDP; electricity exports have also fallen in line with the general economic decline in the region. In contrast, residential consumption of electricity has more than doubled over the same period. As the economy stabilizes and begins a gradual recovery, power and heat consumption can be expected to grow slowly, but at a somewhat slower pace than that of GDP. It is expected that agriculture and services will lead economic recovery and the future role of industry will be less than before independence. It is further expected that the Government will shift away from its present policy of promoting the use of electricity for uneconomic purposes, such as switching residential and commercial consumers to electrical heating, which has led to significant increases in residential use of electricity and overloading of the transmission and distribution network in recent years (para. 2.11). 2.18 Assuming, in accordance with the Bank's macro projections, an average annual GDP growth rate of 3-5 % through the end of the decade, power sales could be expected to rise by 2- 4% per annum on average, while heat sales could be expected to increase in the next couple of years (as KNEHC reduces its rationing) and then level off as sales to new consumers are offset by improved efficiency of heat supply; indicative power and heat sales forecasts are in Annex 2.5. Present power generation and heat production capacities would be expected to be sufficient to meet this demand through at least 2000, including leaving a margin for electricity exports of 1,500 GWh or more a year. To ensure adequate reliability and efficiency in supplying demand, KNEHC's priority investments in the near-medium term include: (a) rehabilitation, upgrading and extension of the power transmission and distribution system; (b) rehabilitation and upgrading of the district heating systems in Bishkek and Osh; and (c) retrofitting of the CHP plant in Bishkek. Priorities over the medium-longer term include: (a) completion of the Tashkumir and Shamaldisai hydropower plants; (b) overhaul and retrofitting of existing hydropower plants, e.g., Utchurgan and At Bashi; and (c) upgrading of the telecommunication and network control systems. Addition of new generating and production capacity will only be justified once there is sufficient demand; development of large scale investments for power exports, such as the Kambarata 1 and 2 hydropower projects, as well as completion of the 220-kV line to China, would have to be linked to long-term power sales agreements. 2.19 In addition to the proposed project, EBRD and Switzerland are also providing assistance in rehabilitation, upgrading and limited extension of KNEHC's transmission system. A framework transmission and distribution system master plan has been prepared with assistance from USAID as part of preparation for the Bank's project. An assessment of the condition and potential for modernization and expansion of the district heating systems in Bishkek and Osh was

A social impact assessment of the proposed tariff increases was carried out with the help of local consultants during project preparation and appraisal: a brief summary is in Annex 2.6, and the full report is in the project file. The assessment was based on: (a) in-depth interviews and focus-group discussions with concerned consumers, NG(O representatives and government officials; (b) data from the Kyrgyz Republic Household Energy Survey undertaken in October 1994 by the Energy Advisory Group (EU-TACIS) in conneclion with the Bank's Energy Sector Review; and (c) a special household survey of consumers usinge district heating in Bishkek carried out in June/July 1995. The surveys revealed somewhat higlher income levels among the concerned population than generally assumed and allowed a better assessment of people's ability to pay for energy, in particular electricity and various sources of household heat and hot water (district heating, natural gas, coal, fuel wood and dung). 2.27 The findings of the assessment indicate that the proposed tariff increase for households for electricity is feasible, while the increase for district heating is feasible only if a social satetv net is introduced to protect low-income households. In parallel, households without access tO district heating, and therefore relying on natural gas and coal for heat, also need protection. In the case of electricity, the impact of the tariff increase could be mitigated through maintainin- a reduced lifeline tariff of 100 to 150 kWh/month for residential consumers; this could be offset by a slightly higher average tariff increase (perhaps 20 tyins/kWh, with 15 tyins/kWh for tle lifeline tariff). At the same time, GOK agreed that KNEHC should terminate by Jul? 1, 1997. all special discounts for household use of power and heat. 2.28 In the case of district heating, based on the social assessment and discussions with tlle Government and other concerned groups, a proposed social safety net has been designed to: (a) protect the poor and vulnerable groups of the population while ensuring that they pay what they can afford; and (b) cause the higher income groups to pay the real cost of supply. A second underlying principle is that KNEHC, which is expected to operate on a commercial basis, should not be subsidizing the low-income consumers; rather this should be the responsibility of the Government under the administration of agencies charged with and qualified to address suchi social responsibilities. The amount of subsidy has been based on the principle that payments for heat and hot water should not exceed 30% of household income. Based on the survey findings, this means about 35% of households with access to district heating would require assistance in paying their heating bills, amounting to an estimated annual cost to the Government of 56 million soms (US$ 5.1 million). Similar analyses were carried out for the population using natural gas and coal for heating, for which the required subsidies are estimated respectively to be 16 and 78 million soms. The Ministry of Labor and Social Protection would be administering the subsidy scheme in view of their experience in targeting low-income groups (including GOK's on-going program of monthly income support benefitting households with incomes below 68 soms/month).6 In an effort to ensure payment goes to the suppliers of heat, the subsidy would be provided in the form of coupons for use in paying heating and gas bills and purchasing coal. A possible source of funding for the subsidy is a tax on power exports or an additional tax on gasoline. GOVERNMENT'S SECTOR STRATEGY 2.29 Sector Reform, Restructuring, Commercialization and Privatization. As indicated in Chapter 1 (para 1.16), a central element of the Government's post-independence policy for the e:nergy sector has been restructuring energy entities to increase autonomy and self-sufficiency, attracting private sector participation to improve efficiency and mobilize financing, and estahblishing the necessary legal and regulatory framework. Consistent with these policies, GOK has expressed interest in privatizing the power and heat sector and has considered various options in this respect, one of which includes gradual privatization of KNEHC as a vertically intetrated power and heat utility. At the urging of the Bank and other donors and as discussed in the Bank's Energy Sector Review, GOK has decided to defer KNEHC's privatization until the various options for restructuring the power and heat sector have been thoroughly analyzed atnd the necessary steps precedent to privatization taken. 2 .30 'T'he absence of a legal and regulatory framework and weaknesses in the overall orvanization of the energy sector have frustrated GOK's efforts to reorganize the power and heat sector and privatize certain activities. Since 1994, however, under the aegis of EU-TACIS and more recently with USAID-funded assistance, a framework energy law and an electricity law have been drafted and submitted to Parliament. This new legislation will provide for licensing and regulation of the power sector, thus helping to create an enabling environment for private sector participation; the energy law will also provide for an independent regulatory agency that would enforce the rights and obligations of the respective parties. In the meantime, the regulatory agency has been created by a Government Act. Continuing assistance from USAID will help GOK implement the new legislation, particularly in setting up, staffing and initiating operation of the regulatory agency and preparation of secondary legislation. As introduction (t' the legislation is considered critical to GOK's plans for sector reform, restructuring and uiltimate privatization, enactment of the energy and electricity laws, satisfactory to IDA, is a condition of effectiveness. 2.31 The power and heat sector in the Kyrgyz Republic has been operated by a single, vertically integrated entity for more than thirty years. Consideration needs to be given to alternative structures for the sector and possible privatization. Separation of electricity and district heating activities, and unbundling of power into generation, transmission and distribution activities should be among the restructuring options to be considered. Divestiture of assets/activities and scope for private sector participation, including independent power producers and local distributors of electricity and district heating, should also be considered. Privatization of the distribution entities seems worth pursuing. Assistance in formulating such a long-term strategy for restructuring the power and heat sector and opening it to private investment will be provided under the proposed project in conjunction with USAID. 2.32 True commercialization and financial and corporate restructuring of KNEHC are essential steps in the utility's transition from a centralized system to a market economy and in its preparation for privatization. Under Japanese Economic Cooperation Fund (JECF) financing, F3BRD is assisting KNEHC to establish a commercial management system; ADB is grant-
 The Power and Heat Sector 17 financing a tariff study and assistance to KNEHC in tariff setting (para 2.25); under the proposed project, IDA is providing assistance in setting up a consumer billing and management system; the Energy Advisory Group funded by EU-TACIS has also provided various assistance concerning KNEHC's commercialization. 2.33 Energy Policy. Faced with sharply rising prices for imported energy and a desire to be self-sufficient, the Kyrgyz Government has stressed increased reliance on indigenous energy supplies and development of its domestic resources. However, the Government's present policy of converting residential and commercial consumers to electrical heating, because electricity is an indigenous resource, is misguided and costly to the economy because: (a) electrical heating costs about three times that of heating with coal or natural gas (Annex 2. 7); (b) the power transmission and distribution system is being seriously overloaded and requires rehabilitation and expansion to carry the additional load (which comes at the time of peak demand); (c) the domestic coal industry is being hurt by the policy; and (d) domestic power consumption would displace exports. Adjustment of electricity tariffs to cover the full cost of supply and subsequent elimination of distortions among relative energy prices should assist consumers in making the proper economic choice for heating. The need to temper its policy promoting domestic use of electricity with economy and efficiency considerations was discussed with GOKIKNEHC during appraisal; assurances to this effect were given by GOK. 2.34 Regional trade will continue to be critically important to the Kyrgyz Republic, as it is a small land-locked country and is fully integrated with its neighboring countries. The trade-offs between competing electricity and irrigation needs for water, as well as the trade of natural gas, petroleum products and coal, pose important challenges to regional economic cooperation. Efforts to improve its energy trade arrangements and negotiate longer term contracts with more equitable sharing of benefits will continue to be a priority for the Kyrgyz Government. Hydropower exports represent a potential growth area for the economy provided markets can be arranged on secure and profitable conditions. USAID is providing some assistance in this area on a regional basis through market studies and a proposed series of conferences on energy and related issues involving participants from the five Central Asian republics; the Bank will also participate in these conferences. ADB is also providing assistance on regional market studies. G. BANK'S ASSISTANCE STRATEGY AND EXPERIENCE 2.35 Bank's Role and Assistance Strategy. A Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for the Kyrgyz Republic was discussed by the Board of Executive Directors on June 28, 1995. The Bank's FY96-98 CAS has been designed to reflect the country's evolving needs and priorities. The basic objectives of the Bank's strategy are to: (a) facilitate restoration of growth; (b) support consolidation of structural reform efforts; (c) assist GOK in protecting the most vulnerable segments of society during the transition; and (d) strengthen institutional capacity. Within these goals, energy has been identified as one of four priority areas for Bank financial and technical assistance. 2.36 In energy, as in other sectors, GOK has shown a firm commitment to reform and looks to the Bank for guidance and assistance. The reform agenda outlined in the Bank's Energy Sector Review prepared in 1994 (para 1.2) is generally consistent with the Government's post- independence energy policy, and actions have been initiated on several fronts with assistance from the Bank and other donors. The Bank's overall role in the sector is to assist in: (a)

Through the proposed project, the Bank, together with ADB, DANIDA, EBRD, Nordic Development Fund, Switzerland, USAID and possibly other donors, will assist the Government and KNEHC in: (a) strengthening sector policy formulation and management, establishing a suitable regulatory framework, and restructuring and commercializing KNEHC with a view to future private participation in the power and heat sector; and (b) carrying out priority rehabilitation and upgrading of the CHP plant and district heating system in Bishkek and the transmission and distribution system in the northern part of the country. Further discussion of regional trade issues, particularly the potential for power exports, may be appropriate in the context of the second project. 2.37 Past Experience and Lessons Learned. The main problems encountered in the Bank's first three years of lending operations in the Kyrgyz Republic have been delays in procurement (particularly of technical assistance and consultant services), inadequate counterpart funding and shortage of qualified local staff. The proposed project would be the first lending operation in the Kyrgyz Republic in the energy sector but, within the context of the Rehabilitation Credit (Cr. 2491-KG), KNEHC was exposed to some extent to Bank processes and procedures. Early establishment of the Project Implementation Unit and staffing it with international experts to assist in development and tendering of bid documents should help minimize start-up delays; terms of reference for key technical assistance activities have been agreed. INSTITUTIONAL FRAMEWORK 3.1 The power and heat sectors have historically been owned and operated by one entity formed initially in 1963 by the Ministry of Energy of the Soviet Union. In April 1992, following a Presidential Resolution, it adopted the name of the Kyrgyz State Electricity Company (KSEC). Early 1994, its name was changed to that of the Kyrgyz National Energy Holding Company (KNEHC). The articles of association of KNEHC', are unusual in that they concentrate most of the powers with the President of the Company. The Board, which is made up exclusively of KNEHC personnel appointed by the President, has limited authority. 3.2 As can be seen at Annex 3. 1, KNEHC operates through twenty one "enterprises" of which sixteen are entrusted with power generation, transmission and distribution, district heating, operation and maintenance (O&M), stores and training - these are the "core enterprises"; and five "enterprises" are engaged in training, design and research, construction and steel frames manufacturing. 3.3 KNEHC functions, for all practical purposes, as the headquarters of a single utility and not as a holding company managing a portfolio of investments in subsidiaries. Its organization chart appears at Annex 3.2. In addition to the heads of the enterprises, eleven individuals report to the President of the company, including two Vice Presidents (one in charge of technical operations, the other of administrative and commercial aspects); four Executive Directors overseeing capital construction, external affairs, development planning and capital construction; and five Department Heads in charge of fairly small units (personnel, accounting, economic matters, finance, security). This structure is unusual in that a large number of individuals report to the President. Furthermore, units that one would normally find under one vice presidency in other utilities (finance, accounting, commercial, economic matters) are spread in KNEHC's case to an unreasonable number of units, which is not conducive to efficient decision making. 3.4 The Government has expressed the desire to privatize the power sector, and some plans were formulated in this respect. However, it now recognizes that the specific nature of the power and heat businesses is such that considerable preparatory work is required prior to privatizing. Given: (i) the unusual set up of KNEHC as a holding company; (ii) the centralized organizational structure; and (iii) the necessity to streamline and commercialize the company operations prior to its privatization, it is proposed to undertake, under the proposed project, an organization study. With respect to the formulation of an appropriate strategy, the proposed study will help the Government identify the various options at its disposal for power sector restructuring, and subsequently assist the authorities in implementing the agreed recommendations. With respect to KNEHC, the study will examine inter alia: (i) the by-laws of KNEHC; (ii) the organization of the company and its subsidiaries; (iii) the financial structure and performance, including the establishment of financial goals and the feasibility of converting equity into debt; (iv) the upgrading of the personnel management function; and (v) the introduction of a management information system. STAFFING 3.5 KNEHC and its "enterprises" employ altogether some 15,200 staff of which about 25% are professional, and the balance, technicians and laborers. Given the scope of activities of KNEHC, the company is considerably overstaffed by western standards. Apparently, staff size corresponds to the norms in effect in the FSU; this implies inter alia that for every senior position, there is a "back-up" candidate should the senior position become vacant for one reason or another. This can also be explained by the large number of construction personnel now idle, the relatively low level of computerization, and excessive parceling of job descriptions. At the same time, the company lacks personnel with experience in the modern tools of power system planning, load management, power economics, tariff setting, data processing, international contracts, etc. The personnel management issues at KNEHC will be studied under the organization study (para. 3.4). C. TRAINING 3.6 The company recruits graduates of vocational schools who are assigned to training programs in the different skills required for the company at KNEHC facilities. Once they successfullv complete the program, they are assigned to one of the "enterprises" of the group (the "enterprises" do not recruit directly senior personnel). Regarding engineers, of whom 25 are recruited annually, selected candidates have their studies paid for by KNEHC. 3.7 In addition to the training of young recruits, the company operates an in-house training program. Furthermore, under the aegis of EU-TACIS and USAID, training programs particularly for the upper management level personnel have been initiated. Nevertheless, the overall scope of KNEHC's training needs and priorities remain to be established. It is therefore proposed under the project to provide for: (i) a consultancy aimed at formulating KNEHC's training needs and priorities over the coming three years. including the areas less emphasized in the past (accounting and auditing, commercial function, financial management, international power contracts, power planning etc.); and (ii) the implementation of the first phase of the training program. D. CUSTOMER MANAGEMENT, BILLING AND COLLECTION 3.8 Until recently, all electricity connections were metered. In the past year, however, as a result of the campaign to enhance electricity use (some 120,000 customers were connected over 1993-94), an unknown number of connections was added, without being metered2. In view of the detrimental impact of unmetered connections on the financial well-being of the utility, assurances were obtained at negotiations (i) that, starting January 1, 1997, new meters will be owned by KNEHC, and will be paid for through a monthly fee, and (ii) by January 1998, KNEHC will 2 In the Kyrgyz Republic, unlike most countries, new customers have now to finance or provide the meter when connected to the grid.
 The Beneficiay 21 ensure that all power consumers are appropriately metered. Residential customers are expected to read their meters on a monthly basis, bring the records to a bank (or a KNEHC cash office) and make the appropriate payment. Inspectors from KNEHC ensure that payment obligations are complied with. The meters of industrial customers are read on a monthly basis, and a bill is issued accordingly. 3.9 Regarding district heating, household and commercial customers are not metered - payments are related to the size of the premises for heat and to the number of persons for hot water. Domestic customers are usually grouped into buildings, and payments are made on a collective basis. As for industrial consumers, they are metered and billed monthly. 3.10 Given the rapidly increasing energy costs, there has been a deterioration in the recovery of payments, so much so that in March 1995, the President of KNEHC issued instructions providing, inter alia, for monthly meter reading and billing, accelerated payment transfers and improved monitoring of cash collections. These efforts are showing results, with an increasing number of customers being disconnected on account of non-payment. Further, during August 1995, the Government settled its debt, and those of the administration, against the taxes due by KNEHC. 3.11 Technical assistance, of limited scope, has been provided in the past (by EU-TACIS and USAID) to improve KNEHC's performance in billing and collection. Under the project, it is proposed to finance a technical assistance program designed to investigate the whole billing cycle in the main areas where KNEHC supplies electricity and heat, and develop and initiate implementation of an improved customer billing and management system. Assurances were obtained during negotiations that: (i) by December 31, 1996, KNEHC will appoint a consultant to carry out the billing and collection study in accordance with terms of reference attached in Annex 3.4; (ii) reviewf with IDA the findings and recommendations of the study; and (iii) implement the agreed recommendations. E. ACCOUNTS AND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT 3.12 KR follows the FSU code of accounts, which is different from the International Accounting Standards (IAS). Further, the Ministry of Finance issues annually detailed instructions regarding the presentation of accounts. Financial statements are prepared on a quarterly basis - the initial financial statements are prepared by the "enterprises", and these are subsequently consolidated by KNEHC. Accounts are produced remarkably fast, within 15 days from the end of the period by the "enterprises", and within 25 days by KNEHC. 3.13 KNEHC is not equipped with a modern management information system, or for that matter, a budgetary control system. Further, there is no costing system which would enable the management to take rational decisions from a financial standpoint. This seems to be due to the framework under which the utility operated previously, in which such matters were not emphasized. Lastly, the company is under equipped in computing equipment. As a result, essential decisions are not supported by documented analyses of their financial implications. Under the circumstances, the upgrading of the accounting and financial functions represents a high priority and a particularly challenging task which is considered critical for the future development of the utility.
 22 The Beneficiary 3.14 Under the aegis of EBRD, an international consultant is at present: (i) investigating the existing accounting practices, management information and financial systems; (ii) designing new systems of reporting, accounting manuals, procedures, costing, management information; and (iii) assisting in the implementation of the new systems. Further, the consultant will provide training, transfer know how, assist in the preparation of the 1995 accounts in accordance with IAS, assist in the revaluation of assets, and more generally, assist KNEHC staff in managing its finances. In view of the critical importance of this consultancy to the improvement/ modernization of KNEHC's financial systems, Bank staff, in liaison with EBRD, have been monitoring progress, and providing inputs, as necessary. AUDIT 3.15 Accounts of State "enterprises" are not subject to an external audit - the tax authorities do their own review, but it cannot be construed as a full audit in line with the IDA's requirements. Consistently with agreements reached previously with EBRD, during negotiations, assurances were obtained that, from FYI 996 onwards, the accounts of KNEHC and those of its subsidiaries will be subject to an independent annual audit by an audit firm acceptable to IDA, and that the results of such audit will be submitted to IDA not later than 6 months from the end of the fiscal year. G. INSURANCE 3.16 KNEHC's power plants, transmission lines, distribution systems, vehicles, are not insured at present. This is due to the absence of an insurance industry in the Kyrgyz Republic. The lack of insurance coverage represents a serious risk for KNEHC given its limited resources. At negotiations, assurances were obtained that KNEHC will take out and maintain appropriate insurance.  IV. THE PROJECT A. PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND DESCRIPTION 4.1 The main objectives of the proposed Project are to support economic growth through rehabilitation and upgrading of the electricity and heat supply infrastructure and to assist the Government in restructuring the power and district heating sector. Specific objectives are to: (i) improve the power and district heating system efficiency and reliability; (ii) reduce power and heat losses; (iii) reduce the environmental impact of the power and heat facilities; (iv) rehabilitate the existing assets in the power and district heating system; (v) introduce appropriate financial management at KNEHC; (vi) restructure KNEHC along commercial lines; and (vii) attract private sector interest in petroleum exploration and production. B. PROJECT DESCRIPTION 4.2 The proposed project would finance priority investments in the energy sector. Its components include: a. For KNEHC: (i) Part A: rehabilitation of the Bishkek combined-heat-and-power (CHP) plant, TES- 1: refurbishment of boilers No.14 to 20; completing the installation of a 90-MW turbo- generator; upgrading the instrumentation and control equipment; and installing emission monitoring devices; (ii) Part B: district heating (DH) system rehabilitation: replacing the corroded network sections and insulation on the aerial sections; installing variable speed pumps to convert the system to variable-flow operation from the present constant-flow/variable temperature operation and modernization of substations including installation of meters; (iii) Part C: rehabilitation and upgrading of power transmission and distribution facilities by way of constructing new stations and retrofitting of essential equipment for selected substation and provision of metering equipment and tools; and (iv) Part D: technical support and training: provision of consultant services to assist KNEHC in implementing the proposed project; assistance in improving billing and collection practices; institutional study aimed at developing a strategy for restructuring the power/heat sector and preparing KNEHC for commercialization; and training of KNEHC staff in priority areas; and b. For the Government: Part E: provision of consultant services and training to assist GOK preparing a petroleum exploration promotion for the most attractive Kyrgyz sedimentary basins, including Fergana Valley. A description of the project components is given below and in detail at Annex 4.1.

Rehabilitation of the Bishkek combined-heat-and-power (CHP) plant - TES-1. 4.3 As indicated in para 2.11, the Bishkek TES-I plant need to be refurbished. The overall efficiency of the plant in co-generation of power and heat mode of about 70% could be improved through retrofitting better instrumentation and control and refurbishment of boilers. Further the installed capacity could be increased by commissioning the 90 MW turbine (Turbine-I 1) purchased from Russia and currently in storage. The proposed Project will provide for the refurbishment of seven most recent boilers; installation of Turbine-I 1, upgrading of the plant instrumentation and control systems and retrofitting of the essential auxiliary system (coal supply, water make up, compressed air, electrostatic precipitators); installation of monitoring devices for emissions (S02, NOx, etc.); and provision for a metal testing laboratory and vibration monitoring equipment. h. Part-B. District heating system rehabilitation in Bishkek 4.4 As indicated in para 2.16, the proposed project would: (a) rehabilitate the DH network through replacement of the most corroded network sections (about 12.5 kin) with pre-insulated pipe to seal leaks and reduce internal corrosion, and replace damaged and poor insulation of the aerial sections of the network (about 7 km); (b) modernize the DH system by introducing variable flow into the system through the installation of frequency converters on selected pumps and by retrofitting the automatic control system necessary to get full benefit of the variable flow operation; and (c) modernize substations to adapt to variable flow operation and install hcat meters. c. Part-C. Rehabilitation and upgrading of the transmission and distrihulion Jacilitie.s. 4.5 The recent increase in electricity demand has subjected the transmission and distribution infrastructure to severe overload. Further, about 60% of the substation equipment in Bishkek has accumulated over 25 years of operation, is currently obsolete and prone to failure creating power outages and safety hazards. The proposed project would finance: (a) construction of a new 220/1 10-kV Ala Archa substation to improve power supply to Bishkek and reduce losses; (b) connection at 220-kV of the Chui substation to improve supply in the area; (c) replacement of the 11 0-kV ground circuit breakers for 12 substations in Bishkek; (d) upgrading the substations of Novo-Troitskaia (1 10/35/10-kV), Orto Alysh (1 10/35/10-kV), Selektsionnaia (1 10/10-kV) and Sel' elecktro (35/10-kV); (e) construction of a new 220/1 10-kV substation at Naryn;' and (f) provision for metering equipment and tools. d Part D. Technical support and training. Construction of the 220/1 10-kV Naryn substation would provide a permanent supply to Naryn region at 220-kV (instead of I 10-kV) and drastically improve the supply to Kumtor Gold Mine and Issyk-Kul and Naryn regions. The following upstream investments of about US$6 million are being carried out under an EBRD- financed operation: (a) completion of the remaining 47 km of the 220-kV transmission line Kemin-Naryn; (b) provision of a 220-kV bay at Kemin; and (c) construction of a provisional 220/1 10-kV substation at Naryn. These works are expected to be commissioned by end 1996.

ENVIRONMENTAL ASPECTS 4.17 The impact of three project components, Bishkek CHP, DH and T&D networks rehabilitation (environmental category B) was assessed in the course of the preparation of the feasibility study and an environmental analysis was carried out during appraisal. During negotiations KNEHC agreed on the implementation of the environmental management plan attachedl in Annex 4.7 and submission to IDA of the reports required under such plan. 4.18 Biishkek (CHP Rehahilitation. The review revealed that (a) the lack of automatic controls leads to losses and high emissions; emissions of S02, NOx and fly ash are not monitored; because the coal used has low sulphur content, emissions of S02 do not present a major problem; fly-ash emissionis could be reduced by better maintenance of the scrubbers and electrostatic precipitators, and connecting in the future all the boilers to the 300-meter high stack; (b) the control ot cxcess air in combustion is very difficult because of uncontrolled air leaking through the boiler walls; (c) measures need to be implemented to reduce the impact of the ash dump on the environment, and (d) asbestos has been used as an insulating material; therefore, measures need to be taken to minimize the risks to workers involved in the removal of this material. The project would address most of these issues: much of the obsolete instrumentation and control equipment will be replaced. The refurbishment of boilers will reduce air leaks; equipment to monitor environmental emissions will be provided. In addition, steps need to be taken to assure that asbestos is safely removed and disposed of, in consultation with environmental authorities. Under the proposed Project technical assistance would be provided to Goskompriroda for the preparation of asbestos disposal and management guidelines. Hence, when implemented, this component would have a favorable environmental impact. 4.19 DII rehabilitation and modernization. Implementation of the proposed component is anticipated to have positive environmental benefits through improved efficiency in the use of fuels and reduction of water losses in the DH system. The energy efficiency would result from a better integration of the DH system and an increased use of the Bishkek CHP as a source of heat, leaving the HOBs for peaking use only. The environmental review assessed potential impacts associated with waste disposal. In the older parts of the DH network, asbestos has been used as an insulating material; therefore, measures need to be taken to minimize the risks to workers involved in the removal of this material. 4.20 T&D network rehabilitation. Except for the Ala Archa and Naryn substations, all of the work to be undertaken is within existing facilities and would not pose any environmental issues. The site of the new Ala Archa substation is outside the city and would not present any environmental issue. The site of the Naryn substation is located in a rural area. Rehabilitation of obsolete and out of repair equipment would contribute to greater safety for the workers and the public. There will be no resettlement issue associated with the project.  VI. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION A. PROJECT BENEFITS 6.1 The physical components of the proposed project--rehabilitation and upgrading of the Bishkek CHP plant, Bishkek district heating system, and transmission and distribution facilities in zhe north--will provide the following benefits: (a) reduced power, heat and water losses; (b) increased effective capacity to supply and deliver power and heat; (c) reduced power outages and improved voltage stability; (d) improved dispatching of heat supply; (e) reduced operating and maintenance costs; (f) reduced environmental impact; and (g) extended life of the rehabilitated assets. 6.2 The primary benefits of the technical support and training component--including project preparation and implementation support, and assistance in policy development and institutional strengthening--will comprise: (a) enhanced project management capabilities within KNEHC; (b) improved financial viability of KNEHC (through improved consumer billing/collections, rationalized tariff setting, establishment of clear financial targets, etc.); (c) strengthened financial and organizational management of KNEHC; (d) progress toward KNEHC's commercialization; and (e) enhanced prospects for private sector involvement in the power and heat sector (through establishing a suitable legal/regulatory framework and developing a strategy for sector restructuring/privatization). 6.3 For the petroleum exploration promotion component, the benefit will be the attraction of investments from the international oil industry with state-of-the-art technology and offering a real possibility of finding oil and gas reserves in the Kyrgyz Republic. B. ECONOMIC EVALUATION 6.4 The proposed project is the least-cost alternative for the supply of heat in the city of Bishkek and for maintaining an acceptable level of reliability and availability of power supply to the economy. The project preparation consultants (financed by USAID and EU-TACIS) carried out a detailed assessment of the condition and need for rehabilitation and upgrading of the Bishkek CHP plant and district heating system, and of the country's transmission and distribution facilities. Alternatives to district heating, including decentralized natural gas and electrical resistance heating, were also evaluated, and a framework transmission and distribution system master plan prepared. In the case of the Bishkek CHP plant and DH system, an economic model was developed during the feasibility study to simulate system operation with and without the project and estimate the associated costs of supplying power, heat and process steam to the Bishkek area. In the case of the transmission and distribution facilities, load flow models were developed for the Bishkek area and a representative rural area (Kalinin under the Chu Electric Company) to assist in identifying system needs, evaluating alternative reinforcement schemes, prioritizing investment alternatives and quantifying project benefits; to the extent possible, these findings were extrapolated to assess the overall situation of the country's transmission and distribution system. In addition, a supplemental study financed by the Swiss government carried out a detailed evaluation of the 220-kV interconnection between Kemin and Naryn. A brief description of the models and key assumptions is given in Annex 6.1 (Bishkek CHP plant and DH system) and Anne-x 6.2 (transmission and distribution facilities), with full details in the project feasibility study and supplemental report (Kemin-Naryn interconnection) in the project file.
 40 Project Justification 6.5 The economic evaluation carried out during project appraisal is limited to the three main physical components and associated technical assistance and is based on the findings of the project preparation consultants. Investment costs are based on project costs inclusive of implementation assistance and physical contingencies and exclusive of price contingencies and customs duties and taxes. All other costs are based on financial costs excluding price contingencies and duties/taxes; energy costs are similarly based on current import (e.g., coal, natural gas and fuel oil) or export (electricity) prices including transport and excluding duties/taxes. In the case of the Bishkek CHP plant and DH system, the main benefits are cost savings in terms of reduced energy and operation and maintenance (O&M) costs to meet the same level of demand. In the case of the transmission and distribution facilities, the main benefits are reduced losses and outages. Power and heat demand forecasts are consistent with those used in the financial analysis; these are somewhat below estimates in the Bank's Energy Sector Review in line with the Bank's current macro projections for the Kyrgyz Republic and taking into consideration the project's expected impact on system operation and losses. The analysis is done in US dollars using constant 1995 prices and exchange rate. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the overall project is conservatively estimated as 30%, which is acceptable (12% is assumed as the opportunity cost of capital for the country); the overall net present value (NPV) is US$ 89 million. The project economic analysis by project component is summarized below; supporting details are in Annexes 6.1 and 6.2. 6.6 Bishkek CHP Plant and District Heating System. The Bishkek CHP plant, as the only major power generating station in the northern part of the Kyrgyz Republic, plays a key role in the power supply of the region and the country as a whole. It is also the main supplier of the Bishkek district heating network and supplies heat and power at significantly lower cost/higher efficiency than heat-only boilers and power-only coal-fired thermal stations.' The project includes only the highest priority rehabilitation components which are essential for restoring/maintaining plant operations. 6.7 The Bishkek district heating system provides heat and hot water to over half of the city's population and process steam to various industries. A detailed assessment of alternative means of meeting the city's heating needs using electrical heating and natural gas was carried out during the feasibility study. In the case of electrical resistance heating, investment costs in transmission and distribution capacity only (excluding generating capacity) would be about US$ 270 million, plus another US$145 million for adjustments to heating systems within the apartment buildings; annual production costs (electricity and O&M) would be on the order of US$80 million. In the case of decentralized natural gas heating, the required investment costs would be about US$160 million (US$50 million in the gas network to bring sufficient gas at adequate pressure to the areas now served by district heating and US$ 110 million in adjustments to heating systems within the buildings) and annual production costs US$ 30 million. Rehabilitation of the Bishkek CHP plant and the existing district heating system (base cost US$ 43 million and annual production costs US$32 million) is clearly the least cost and most feasible alternative, now and in the foreseeable future. I/ Comparative fuel efficiency figures for coal, for example, are 115% and 45% respectively for heat and power in a CHP plant, and 80% and 35% in separate heat and power units.
