PROJECT RISKS 6.14 The project is not expected to have detrimental effects on the environment and presents no unusual physical risks since it involves rehabilitation and upgrading work on standard generation, district heating, and transmission and distribution facilities. The main risks that may cause problems in project implementation include: (a) front-end delays; (b) inadequate project management capabilities of KNEHC; and (c) KNEHC's weak financial condition which may lead to unavailability of counterpart funds. Measures have been incorporated in the project design to reduce these risks. Early establishment of the Project Implementation Unit and staffing it with qualified local personnel and selected international experts to assist in engineering design, procurement and construction supervision will facilitate timely project start-up. The project includes technical support and training activities that will help KNEHC staff to strengthen their project management and operation skills. Technical support is also being provided, under the project as well as by other donors, to enable KNEHC to improve its financial management and commercialize its operations. For example, KNEHC's billing and collection practices will be modernized, tariff setting mechanism rationalized to enable full cost recovery and financing of its development program, and accounting systems upgraded to international standards; establishment of and adherence to sound financial targets will also help to ensure the availability of counterpart funds. Technical support provided during project preparation and implementation will also help to mitigate the risks of cost overruns during the project and reduced benefits once the works are completed. Moreover, as demonstrated by the sensitivity analyses carried out during project appraisal (paras. 6.10, 6.13), the project investments are viable over a reasonable range of such risks. 6.15 There is also a risk associated with the political sensitivity of energy price increases and energy sector restructuring measures. However, the Government is strongly committed to economic reform as demonstrated by its past actions, and the changes will be introduced in a phased manner to ameliorate the impact. For example, the draft energy and electricity legislation, an important early step in the power and heat sector's transition process, was submitted to Parliament in February 1996 and is expected to be approved by end-September 1996; the State Energy Agency was created and its chairman appointed by Presidential acts issued in March 1996; and power and heat tariffs were increased in April 1996, with further adjustments planned in July 1996, together with the introduction of a social safety net for the poor. At the same time, it should be noted that these broader sectoral restructuring efforts are
 Project Justification 45 not critical to the success of the physical project (with the exception of aspects pertaining directly to KNEHC's financial and managerial performance), rather they are important in terms of addressing longer term sectoral objectives. 6.16 For the petroleum exploration promotion component, there is a risk that international oil companies will show no interest either because the potential for oil discoveries and export is perceived as being less promising than elsewhere or because the promotion effort has not been carried out satisfactorily. This would be mitigated by using state-of-the-art technology in compiling the geological data base and highly qualified consultants in carrying out the promotion. The Govermment's adoption of a satisfactory legal and fiscal framework for petroleum, which would facilitate the country's contracting with international oil companies, would be a prerequisite for any disbursements for this component.

 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT KYRGYZ REPUBLIC POWER AND DISTRICT HEATING REHABILITATION PROJECr Annex 2.6 SOCIAL SAFETY NET: RESULTS FROM A SOCIAL ASSESSMENT I. Introduction 1. A social assessment was carried out as part of the project preparation of the Power and District Heating Rehabilitation Project. The objectives of this assessment were to: (i) analyze patterns of fuel use for distinct groups of rural and urban households; (ii) evaluate implications of higher energy costs for residential consumers; (iii) outline elements of an energy strategy for different segments of households and (iv) design a social safety net for protecting the lowest- income households from increased energy costs'. 2. This assessment, undertaken in collaboration with local experts, consisted of the following activities: (i) in-depth interviews and focus group discussions with low-income consumers, NGO representatives, and government officials; (ii) data analysis of the Kyrgyz Republic Household Energy Survey 2 and (iii) a user survey of 150 households on district heat in Bishkek undertaken in June 1995 to better appraise the peoples' capacity and willingness to pay for heating and hot water3. 3. The combined effect of the recent increases of coal and LPG prices and the proposed higher tariffs for heat, hot water, electricity, and gas, will have a major impact on household energy users in the Kyrgyz Republic, particularly among the low-income segment of the population. To mitigate the adverse social effects of these price increases on vulnerable groups, the Government should put in place a suitable social safety net. Based on the results of this social assessment, the key element of such a safety net would require the provision of subsidies to the lowest-income consumers, particularly urban households using (i) district heating and (ii) natural gas for heating and (iii) urban and rural households using coal, firewood and dung for heating. II. Findings of the Social Assessment / Patterns of Household Energy Use 3. This social assessment revealed that the fuel use patterns in the Kyrgyz Republic are determined by three factors: in urban areas, (i) access to district heat and (ii) access to the natural gas network and (iii) in rural areas, the availability of an outside stove for cooking. I The detailed report of this social assessment is available in the project files. 2 This survey, undertaken in October 1994 by the Energy Advisory Group and financed by the European Union, generated a sample comprising of 686 urban and rural households. 3This was a complementary survey which provided data on income and household expenditure on food and energy. The income data showed that the average income of the population on district heat is 920 soms per month; the average income of a one-person household is 397 soms, a 2-person household 713 soms, a 3-person household 822, a 4-person household 1212 soms and 5 and more person household 1413 soms per month. It is remarkable to see that 22 % of the households on district heat in Bishkek earn 1200 soms per month.
 69 Annex 2.6 These factors allow the classification of households into segments and sub-segments of energy users beyond the broad distinction of rural and urban households, providing a more precise picture of distinct fuel use patterns among different groups of households (Chart 1). First, urban households can be divided into households with access to the district heating network, the core- urban households, and households without access to this network, the semi-urban households. Second, these two segments of households can be further subdivided into sub-segments with access to the network of natural gas supply and sub-segments without access to this network. The resulting four sub-segments of urban households are characterized by distinct patterns of fuel use (Charts 2 and 3). Furthermore, the segment of rural households can be divided into 4 households owning a stove for cooking in their yards and households not owning such a stove4. These two sub-segments of rural households also show distinct patterns of fuel use (Chart 4). The identified patterns of fuel use of the different household segments were a key frame of reference for data analysis. These are discussed below in greater detail. 4. Core-Urban Households This group of urban households has access to the district heating network. They comprise 25 % of all households in the Kyrgyz Republic and the vast majority reside in apartment buildings located in the central parts of the cities. Eight out of ten core-urban households live in the city of Bishkek, which has the largest district heating network. Others live in cities also connected to the district heating network namely, Karakol, Karakul, Kyzil Kiya and Osh. 5. While all core-urban households use district heating as the principle means of space heating, their access to the network of the natural gas supply determines the fuel use patterns for cooking and water heating5 (Table 1). Those with access to the natural gas network use natural gas all-year round and almost exclusively, for cooking their main meals, breakfast and snacks as well as heating water, mostly for hot beverages such as tea and coffee. Natural gas is also used to supplement district heating. Focus group discussions with district heat customers revealed that households often use their gas-fired cooking stove to supplement district heating. By contrast, those without access to the natural gas network use electricity mainly for cooking and water heating, also for tea and coffee mainly. To some extent, LPG and firewood are also used. 6. Semi-urban households This group of urban households has no access to district heating. The great majority live in individual, private houses located mostly in the outskirts of the cities. The fuel use patterns of semi-urban households are also largely determined by access to the natural gas network. Those with access to the natural gas network use natural gas for space heating, cooking, and water heating --- almost exclusively in both winter and summer. Other fuels like electricity, coal, firewood, dung are less frequently used. On the other hand, those without access to the 4 This is based on qualitative information provided by local experts. 5 Hot water is also provided as part of district heating. The survey results showed, however, that 93% of core-urban households with gas connection use natural gas for water heating, mainly for making hot beverages such as coffee and tea. Among households without natural gas, 85% use electricity for the same purpose.
 Annex 2.6 70 natural gas network have a much more diversified fuel use pattern, characterized by distinct seasonal variations. In winter, these households use coal and electricity, primarily for space heating and cooking main meals, with firewood used oftentimes as an important complementary fuel, in combination with coal. Moreover, households use electricity or LPG for cooking breakfast, snacks, and heating water for coffee and tea. In summer, electricity is primarily used to cook the main meals as well as breakfast, snacks and heat water. 7. Rural Households Compared to core-urban and semi-urban households, rural households have the most complex pattern of fuel use. They rely on a wider range of fuels because they do not have access to district heating nor the natural gas network. Coal, firewood, dung, electricity and LPG are the fuels used mostly by rural households (Table 1). Qualitative information6 from the field further revealed that households owning a stove for cooking in their yards, comprising about 60 % of rural households, follow a different seasonal pattern of fuel use compared to those not owning such a stove. In summer, the former cook their main meals on those stoves burning firewood, agricultural waste and dung whereas the latter use mainly electricity and LPG (Chart 4). 8. According to local experts, there has been a massive shift to dung, electricity and firewood usage for heating and cooking, as a result of the recent increases in coal and LPG prices. Similarly, results from the household energy survey showed that more than one-third of rural households now use dung as their main heating fuel (Table 2). In addition, nearly three- quarters of households reported using more of dung now for space heating and cooking and about two-thirds use more of electricity now for the same purposes (Table 3). Despite the reported increase in the use of electricity, local experts believe that electricity consumption in rural areas is under-reported because of the high incidence of illegal connections. III. Conclusions and Recommendations: Implications for the Design of Social Safety Net 9. This section describes the implications and potential impacts of the increased energy tariffs on various groups of the population. It also outlines specific recommendations for a social safety net to protect the poorest households that will be hurt the most by the increased tariffs. As a short-to-medium term measure, energy subsidies, in the form of coupons, will be provided to eligible low-income households using district heating, natural gas and coal. Over the long-term, a cost-effective program on household energy-efficiency and conservation is proposed to be established as a follow-up measure to ensure sustainability of reforms in the district heating sector. A summary matrix is provided in Chart 5. 10. District Heating and Hot Water Approximately half of the urban population in the Kyrgyz Republic is provided with heat and hot water from the district heating network, the main source of heating for this population. Other fuels like coal, gas, heating oil, LPG, kerosene or dung are not used for heating. 6 The 1994 Kyrgyz Republic Household Energy Survey used in this Social Assessment did not have data on stove ownership in yards among rural households.

Safety Net Provision for Low-income Households with District Heating In particular, higher tariffs for heat and hot water on low-income consumers would be cushioned through a subsidy scheme which aims to (i) protect poor and vulnerable groups of the population while ensuring at the same time that they pay what they can afford, and (ii) cause higher income groups to pay the real cost of supply. The subsidy design has been guided by the principle to (i) keep KNEHC from accomplishing social functions constraining business performance, and (ii) assign genuine social responsibilities to agencies that are in charge and qualified to assume them.

The portion of the heating and hot water bill over 30% will be subsidized. While such an estimate is high, even for those with adequate income, it represents a mid-point benchmark based on recent empirical data: (1) the reported fuel expenditure share of 22% for low-income households in the Bishkek survey and (2) the expenditure share of about 40% for non-food items for poor urban households estimated in the recent Kyrgyz Republic Poverty Assessment7. Based on the latter non-food expenditure share figure of 40%, the 30% benchmark would mean that the food budget of the poorest household would not be jeopardized although, they will have to make significant adjustments with respect to other non-food requirements. For the lowest-income consumers, the energy price shocks will be extremely difficult to absorb particularly in an environment where low-cost fuel substitutes are not available. 16. Based on a population of about 200,000 households with district heating and on income data collected in this Social Assessment, an estimated 70,000 households would be eligible for the subsidy. The estimated annual cost of the subsidy would amount to approximately 56 million soms. 17. Long-term Project Strategy Since the subsidy is envisioned to be phased out over the short- to medium-term, a more sustainable development program for the district heating sector will have to be considered. This will involve the implementation of a follow-up project to assist households in reducing their costs for heating and hot water. This will consist of two major components: (i) modest investments in energy and water efficiency to rationalize the consumption of hot water by installing hot water meters in the apartments, introducing consumption-based billing, and promoting the conservation of hot water, and (ii) modest investments in energy efficiency to reduce heat losses by improving insulation both at the building (attic, basement) and apartment levels (caulking, weatherstripping) and reduce excessive ventilation in the buildings and apartments. 18. The Bishkek survey showed that the above strategy to improve energy and water efficiency could be successful: 82% of the district heat and hot water customers would welcome consumption-based billing for hot water; 77% would be able and willing to conserve hot water; 40% of the latter would be able to save up to 25% of their actual consumption, whereas 35% of them would be able to save between 25% and 50% of their present consumption; 45% of the respondents would be willing to install such a meter and pay in monthly installments. Natural Gas At present, the sub-segment of semi-urban households with access to the natural gas network suffers most from recent fuel price and related tariff increases, particularly for natural gas. They rely on natural gas as their principal fuel for space heating, cooking and water heating, all-year round. They live mostly in private houses, are not connected to the district heating network and have very limited means to cope with the impact of high natural gas prices because cheaper alternative fuels like dung are not available. This segment of the population pays the highest energy bill -- an average of 250 soms/month, of which 95% accounts for gas consumption (Table 5). 20. Currently, gas consumption is not metered. Consumers pay a flat rate based on usage, the area of the home, and the number of persons in the household. This system does not provide an incentive for energy-saving. Additional reduction of the household energy bill could be achieved through the installation of gas meters, introduction of consumption-based billing and the promotion of gas conservation. 21. Safety Net Provision for Low-income Natural Gas Consumers The beneficiaries of the subsidy would be the low-income semi-urban population connected to the natural gas network. Of the 70,000 households using natural gas for heating and cooking, about 20,000 households are estimated to benefit from the subsidy. These will be given in the form of coupons to be used against payment of natural gas bills. The total cost of the subsidy would amount to about 16 million soms per year. 22. Coal

The most vulnerable are found in urban areas, specifically semi-urban households without natural gas as well as rural households, who rely on coal as their main heating and cooking fuel. The survey data showed that nine out of ten semi-urban households without natural gas use coal as their main heating fuel. In rural areas, relatively fewer households are dependent on coal (60%) since more than one-third use dung as their main heating fuel. 23. Safety Net Provision for Low-income Coal Users The subsidy for urban and rural households would be targeted primarily to households below the poverty line, comprising 175,000 households in rural areas and 21,000 households in urban areas (i.e. semi-urban households without natural gas). The subsidy would be given in the form of a voucher to be used against the purchase of coal, equivalent to the cost of 1 ton per household per year. Based on an average retail price of 400 soms per ton of coal, the subsidy would amount to 78 million soms. 24. Electricity All households rely on electricity mainly for lighting and household appliances, although some households use it as a supplementary heating fuel. The impact of higher electricity tariffs on core-urban households with gas will be low and for those without gas, would be moderate. However, there is very limited scope for fuel substitution among core-urban households because cheaper, alternative fuels are not available in urban areas. For semi-urban households with access to natural gas, the impact of higher electricity tariffs will be moderate given their relatively low level of electricity consumption. The most vulnerable segment are semi-urban households without access to natural gas; their electricity consumption is highest (212 kwh/month) among urban households --- nearly two times higher than semi-urban households without gas. 25. Many semi-urban households access electricity through illegal network connections, and as a result, usage of this fuel has risen significantly. They also have limited scope for fuel substitution and their capacity to adopt adequate coping strategies in an environment of increasing fuel prices is seriously constrained by limited access to cheaper, alternative fuel sources. 26. Rural households will also be affected by higher tariffs in a major way because of their high level of electricity consumption (Figure 4). While they have a broader scope for fuel substitution given the relative availability of free or low-cost fuel sources such as firewood and dung, rural households are beginning to experience the effects of increased demand on these fuel sources. The survey data showed that 78% expressed the opinion that firewood was in great shortage. Firewood is becoming increasingly scarce due to the limited forest cover. Similarly, a declining supply of dung is likely because cattle production in the country has decreased in recent years. 27. Safety Net Provision for Low-income Electricity Users To cushion the impact of higher electricity tariffs on low-income households, a lifeline tariff of 15 tyins/kwh for the first 100 kwh/month consumed should be subsidized.

Participation Public participation is essential for this proposed social safety net and subsidy scheme. The objectives of a participatory approach are to (i) inform the public appropriately, (ii) consult beneficiaries and other stakeholders in order to facilitate qualified contributions from the

To achieve those objectives, the MLSP as the executing agency of the safety net operations would conduct public hearings on the safety net prior to its implementation. The public hearings should be carried out both at the central level and the Ministry's field offices in charge of social assistance. Follow-up hearings should be undertaken, preferably after three to four months, to monitor implementation and gather feedback from the public. Specifically invited to the hearings, particularly at the central level, would be NGO representatives and independent specialist. In addition to the public hearings, the public would be periodically informed through the media on payments carried out, number of beneficiaries targeted as well as the effectiveness of administrative procedures adopted. Financing of this subsidy could come from an additional tax on gasoline. BACKGROUND 1. The Kyrgyz power system comprises 18 hydroelectric plants (altogether 2,774 MW); two combined heat and power plants (altogether 659 MW); a number of heat only boilers; 500-kV lines (541 km), 220-kV lines (1,009 km), 110-kV lines (4,301 km), 35-kV lines (4,172 km), and more than 60,000 km of low voltage distribution lines. The sector supplies electricity to about 975,000 consumers, of which 950,000 are residential, the balance being agricultural, administrative and industrial consumers. Further, it supplies heat (steam and hot water) to five urban centers in the country, primarily for residential, administrative and industrial uses. 2. Following independence, the Government entrusted a single joint stock company with the ownership and operation of the power system. The present organization goes back to 1994, when the holding concept was introduced and the company renamed the Kyrgyz National Energy Holding Company (KNEHC). Under a holding company structure 1, KNEHC operates nineteen main "enterprises" of which sixteen are entrusted with power generation, transmission and distribution; district heating; operation and maintenance; stores and training. Of the remaining three "enterprises" which are actually joint stock companies, two are involved in construction and one in the production of prefabricated concrete structures. KNEHC has attempted to divest these non-core businesses, but with little success thus far. 3. In line with the country's privatization efforts in other sectors, the Govermnent has expressed interest in privatizing the power sector and has considered various options in this respect. Following discussions with donors, the Government has recognized the unique aspects of the power sector, and has decided to defer privatization until the various options have been thoroughly analyzed and the necessary steps precedent to privatization taken. Sector reform/restructuring and commercialization of existing operations are important prerequisites to privatization. The present technical assistance, together with on-going efforts noted below, is designed to address these issues. 4. The relevant on-going technical assistance actions on institutional aspects include: (i) a draft framework law for energy and a draft electricity law have been prepared under the aegis of EU-TACIS and USAID and will have to be discussed and finalized. This new legislation will provide for licensing and regulation of the power sector, thus helping to create an enabling environment for private sector participation; the energy law Which functions more as the headquarters of a company, than as a holding company concerned with managing its investment portfolio in subsidiaries.
 Annex 3.3 91 will also provide for an independent regulatory agency that would enforce the rights and obligations of the respective parties. In addition, the now terminated Energy Advisory Group funded by EU-TACIS has submitted various reports concerning inter alia commercialization of KNEHC; (ii) complementary assistance from USAID will assist the Government in implementing the new legislation, particularly setting up, staffing and initiating operation of the regulatory agency and preparation of model contracts/agreements and secondary legislation; (iii) under JECF financing, EBRD is assisting KNEHC to establish a commercial management system, including modernization of KNEHC's financial practices to bring them into conformity with international accounting standards, introducing cost accounting and financial management information systems, and implementing the above practices/systems and training staff in their use; (iv) assistance from ADB will comprise a power and heat tariff study, a revaluation of assets study, and associated staff training. 5. Close liaison with these on-going tasks will be necessary to avoid duplication of efforts and ensure complementarity of proposed actions and responsiveness to the requirements of the sector and KNEHC. II. OBJECTIVES AND APPROACH 6. The primary objectives of this technical assistance effort are to help the Government: (i) develop an overall strategy for restructuring the power/heat sector with a view to improving sector efficiency and reliability/quality of supply, reducing the drain on the national budget and opening the way to private sector involvement; and (ii) begin to implement this strategy through restructuring and commercialization of KNEHC. 7. Within KNEHC, the primary focus would be on: (i) KNEHC's legal statutes and subsidiaries; (ii) the organizational framework and exercise of management/control over the subsidiaries; (iii) the financial structure and performance; (iv) staffing and manpower management; and (v) management information systems. 8. The study will be carried out in three phases: (a) Task-A: sector strategy formulation; (b) Task-B: diagnostic study of KNEHC; and (c) Task-C: implementation of recommendations. The first two phases will proceed in parallel, with detailed work on the diagnostic phase proceeding only after preliminary agreement has been reached on the long-term structure for the power/heat sector. Execution of the third phase will be subject to agreement on the detailed findings of the diagnostic phase and proposed plan of action prepared by the consultants.
 92 Annex 3.3 III. SCOPE OF WORK 9. Task - A. - Sector Strategy Formulation The consultants will define the structural and implementation details for the sector's transformation under KNEHC. This will involve clarification of the applicable principles and organizational options for sector reform and modernization to achieve the Government's objective of moving administration of the power/heat sector from a central planning mechanism to one which is more market oriented. 10. The consultants will review the options for the longer term organization of the sector with a view to recommending a structure that promotes operational efficiency, efficient investment, reliability and quality of supply, accountability to the owners of its capital, efficient use of electricity and district heating, and which takes into account the needs of consumers. The current and planned organization of the power/heat sector and existing plans for its restructuring, commercialization, corporatization and privatization will be reviewed. The preliminary findings of the diagnostic study below will provide important inputs to this process in terms of identifying the problems and constraints of the present system. The consultants will also coordinate closely with the on-going legal and regulatory work (para. 4) in making their recommendations. 11. Separation of power and heat activities, and unbundling of power into generation, transmission and distribution will be among the restructuring options to be considered. Divestiture of assets/activities and scope for private sector participation, including independent power producers and local distributors, will also be considered. Criteria for evaluating the various options in the Kyrgyz context will be developed and used in assessing the options. 12.  STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT KYRGYZ REPUBLIC POWER AND DiSrRcIT HEATING REHABILITATION PROJECT ANNEx 4.2 PROJECT MANAGEMENT CONSULTING SERVICES: TERMS OF REFERENCE I. BACKGROUND 1. The Kyrgyz electric power system is experiencing serious operating problems due to overloading and insufficient development of its subtransmission and distribution network and the lack of required rehabilitation and reinforcement of its facilities. The lack of rehabilitation has persisted over five years and is affecting reliability of existing facilities. The major problems are: (i) serious overloading of 110 kV subtransmission facilities and distribution networks resulting in heavy losses, voltage drops, power outages and the failure of many transformers; (b) low power factor value due to the lack of reactive supply capability on the subtransmission and distribution systems; and (c) outdated system control and protection equipment threatening system safety and reliability. Without an intensive rehabilitation of the system there is a real risk of major breakdowns. 2. The city of Bishkek has a district heating system which serves about half current population of the city (estimated at 700,000 inhabitants), and process heat to industries. Most of the heat is from a combined-heat-and-power plant TES-1 with a capacity of 609 MW and 1,820 Gcal/h. TES-1 has 24 boilers and 10 turbines some of which date back to the 1960's. The plant need to be refurbished and upgraded in particular concerning instrumentation and control, combustion efficiency and monitoring of emissions. The district heating network consists of 331 km double pipe comprising 157 km of transmission pipelines and 174 km of distribution pipelines. The maximum operating pressure is 16 bars; the maximal temperature is 150 oC with a return temperature of 70 oC. 3. The district heating systems in the Kyrgyz Republic, as in most of the FSU, are recognized to be relatively inefficient. The main causes are: (a) use of a constant flow, variable temperature system with no temperature control or metering at the user end; (b) greater reliance on HOBs which should be used mainly for peaking, and use of old and obsolete equipment combined with inadequate maintenance; and (c) use of transmission and distribution network technology which leads to low life expectancy and high water and heat losses. Heat losses climbed to 19% in 1994, from 7% in 1990-91, due in large part to lack of maintenance in recent years and the deteriorated condition/age of some parts of the country's DH heating system. Given the high cost of fuel, KNEHC and the Government recognize that improvements in the operational efficiency of the DH system are essential to ensure efficient and cost effective delivery of heating services particularly in Bishkek. 4. The objective of the project is to assist KNEHC to carry out rehabilitation and modernization of existing power system and district heating facilities in order to improve overall quality of supply and reliability, reduce occurrence of outages and losses and enhance the efficiency of energy supply. The project would assist in urgently needed rehabilitation and upgrading of transmission, distribution, district heating and power plant facilities in Bishkek and other major load centers where the need is most urgent.

 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT KYRGYZ REPUBLIC POWER AND DISTRIcT HEATING REHABILITATION PROJECT ANNEX 4.3 PETROLEUM EXPLORATION PROMOTION - PHASE C DRAFT TERMS OF REFERENCE KYRGYZ NATIONAL ENERGY HOLDING COMPANY (KNEHC) I. BACKGROUND 1. As a land-locked country with limited supply options, the Kyrgyz Republic has been dependent on Kazakhstan, Russia and Uzbekistan for most of its requirements in fossil fuels. Consumption of oil products and natural gas in 1993 was respectively about 0.9 million tons and 1.3 billion m3, a significant reduction from the 1990 level of 2.7 million tons of oil products and 2.1 billion m3 natural gas. Currently, the Kyrgyz Republic imports in excess of 90% of its petroleum products and natural gas requirements. Energy products account for half of the imports from the FSU. The short term outlook remains unfavorable as the expected increase of natural gas prices to world levels would further deteriorate the energy trade balance. At international prices and 1993 volumes, oil and gas imports would cost over US$200 million per year. 2. Oil and gas production in the Kyrgyz Republic is concentrated in the Fergana Valley in the south from structures that extend westward into Uzbekistan. Production which amounts to less than 100,000 MT/year of crude and 70 million m3 of natural gas from about 400 wells. A comprehensive program for production-rehabilitation in the Fergana basin together with renewed exploration in the basin, is believed to be essential for increasing production. At present crude is processed in the Fergana refinery in Uzbekistan but the processing fee is reported to be high. 3. The territory of Kyrgyz Republic includes margins of two petroliferous provinces, Fergana Basin and Chu-Sarysu Basin which are shared with Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan, respectively. The Fergana intermontane basin is bounded by major faults that separate it from the mountains to the north and south. Traps are anticlinical and many of the anticlines are fault- related folds (with faults possibly playing a part in confining oil pools). Reservoir rocks are represented largely by Paleogene sandstones. As late as few years ago Fergana Basin was considered to be a mature oil producing region. However, recent discoveries in neighboring Uzbekistan may represent the beginning of rejuvenating of this oil and gas province (although new prospective reservoirs are associated with depths of more than 5 km and abnormally high formation pressures). The Kyrgyz part of the Chu-Saryusu basin may also contain sizable petroleum reserves as it is believed to be highly prospective for gas and possibly oil on the territory of Kazakhstan. 4. During the Soviet era, oil exploration in the Kyrgyz Republic was not a priority, given plentiful resources in other republics. Consequently, comprehensive geological and geophysical work was carried out for the most part in the Fergana valley so that several potentially promising oil provinces have yet to be explored. The Alai basin, in the extreme south of the republic, a mountainous region bordering Tajikistan, is the only area where considerable seismic
 109 Annex 4.3 work has been carried out; the single well drilled in that basin had an encouraging show. Other potentially promising areas are the Chui Valley, west of Bishkek, and the Aksai Valley south of Issyk Kul Lake, close to China.. 5. Because of the lack of risk capital, equipment and technology, the Government has concluded that it needs to attract international oil companies with the requisite resources to undertake an petroleum exploration and development efforts, as well as to increase the recovery of oil from producing areas. In this respect, a promotional effort, in 1994, had no positive results, but was probably premature. Several issues have be addressed: (i) the landlocked nature of the country and its remoteness are likely to increase exploration expenditures; (ii) petroleum prospectivity is uncertain and is subject to inter alia additional data acquisition and processing; and (iii) the available exploration and production data need to be gathered and processed in order to be able to present a comprehensive picture to industry. Furthermore, in spelling out an exploration strategy, one will have to consider: (i) preparing different types of packages for the mature Fergana Basin and for other, less explored and unexplored areas; (ii) the size of exploration blocks on the basis of prospective risk/reward for each area; and (iii) model work programs tailored area wise. 6. A successful promotion will also depend on progress in the establishment of an accommodating investment framework, i.e. adequate petroleum prices, reasonable taxation, acceptable legislation and appropriate institutional arrangements. Until such a framework is put in place, any effort would need to precisely spell out the relevant applicable regulations. II. WORK UNDERTAKEN IN PHASE A AND B 7. The assignments already being undertaken in Phase A and B include: (i) Under Phase A (a) assessment of the existing exploration geological and geophysical data; and (b) assessment of data from producing fields; (ii) Under Phase B (a) an improved oil recovery study of existing producing basins; (b) geochemical analyses of drill cuts and source rock; (c) basin modeling; and (d) reprocessing of selected seismic lines. 8. Once Phase B has been successfully completed, the work that would lead to the actual promotion of the basins as defined in the previous phases, will be carried out under Phase C which is the subject of these terns of reference. The scope of work of Phase C will include:- (a) basin analysis;
 Annex 4.3 110 (b) preparation of promotion stately; and (c) implementation of the promotion strategy. 9. Basin Analysis. The consultant will prepare a report on the overall exploration potential of the Kyrgyz Republic. This report will draw information from phases A and B with particular reference to: (i) the geographic spread and quality of available and reprocessed seismic and well data: (ii) stratigraphic analysis and hydrocarbon maturity analyses, and known hydrocarbon indications in the Kyrgyz Republic; and (iii) geological and production data from existing fields. This report will summarize the potential for new discoveries of oil and gas in structures related to existing discoveries, where exploration risk can be minimized. Further, basins will be ranked in terms of their potentate to generate recoverable hydrocarbons, and the data used to generate an overall exploration strategy for the Kyrgyz Republic 12. Development of exploration promotion strategy. The main activities will include: (i) Development of promotional strategy: a report will be prepared which discusses the alternatives of the promotion campaign. The consultant will take into account the potential of the basins as well as the legal and fiscal frameworks. The consultant will estimate the level of interest that can be expected from oil companies. Recommendations will be made on the best form of promotion to attract and target potential investors; (ii) Preparation of data packages: the consultant will produce a data package containing data from the areas to be promoted. The data package will contain location, well test, and production data in a form such as film, paper or digitally on magnetic tape, as deemed appropriate; the data package will also include a technical report and a data catalogue of the blocks. 13. Imnplementation of the promotion strategy. If it is confirmed to be the best option, the consultant will organize and advertise the holding of two international promotional seminars. In addition the consultant will make every effort to advertise the promotion through direct contacts with interested clients world wide. The consultant will prepare a data package License and Non-Disclosure Agreement to be signed by oil companies to use the data, but will restrict how the data is used by their employees. 14. At the conclusion of the seminars, the consultant will provide a report that describes the work undertaken and the results achieved. feedback will be provided from the oil companies, where available, to give the Government a better understanding of the future investment potential in the Kyrgyz Republic.  STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT KYRGYZ REPUBLIC POWER AND DISTRICr HEATING REHABILITATION PROJEcr ANNEX 4.7 ENVIRONMENTAL ANALYSIS I. BISHKEK TES-1 REHABILITATION 1. Introduction The Mission met with the representatives of the Kyrgyz National Holding Company (KNEHC) and with officials of the State Committee on Environmental protection to discuss environmental issues and concerns related to the Proposed Power District Heating Rehabilitation Project. The impacts of three components were assessed and a summary of environmnental analysis in each areas along with Environmental Management Plan are provided below. 2. TES-1 combined heat and power plant has 24 boilers (only five (summer) to fifteen (winter) working at a time) with a total installed capacity of 350 MW of electric generation, over 100 tons per hour of steam production for export to industrial plants and 2,500 cubic meters of hot water production for space heating and supply of hot water to the city of Bishkek. All boilers are equipped to burn coal, oil and gas fuels. Availability of gas supply is uncertain because gas is being imported at a high cost. The boilers are using low grade coal which contains 46% ash and is imported from Kazakhastan. The plant produces the steam at 100 Atm and a temperature of 540 C. In a combined heat and power plant (CHP), the thermal efficiency is about 75 to 80%. Due to small requirement of hot water heating during the summer, the CHP operates mostly on gas and is supplemented by coal on as required basis. 3. Environmental Aspects The boilers are normally running at a very high air to fuel ratio which is contributing towards a significant energy loss in flue gas. To avoid this problem and to optimize energy efficiency, it is recommended that each operation should have a combustion analyzers to measure the amount of excess oxygen in flue gas. The fuel to air ratio can be adjusted with respect to excess air monitored on a regular basis. Later on when the cash flow situation improves, an automatic control system can be used to optimize the boilers performance. These combustion analyzers are about six to eight thousand dollars each and will provide a reasonable tool to adjust the air to fuel ratio for each boiler. 4. Coal Storage Area The lignite coal is being stored outside with no water cooling system provided in the storage area. During the summer time, coal has a tendency to emit volatile gases such as methane which can ignite if the temperature of the coal pile reaches high. It had happened a few times in the past and the fire is extinguished within a short time. In order to protect the coal storage from fire, a water connection at two or three locations along with long hoses is recommended so that it can cover the entire coal pile area. 5. Disposal of Oily Water A significant amount of cooling water being used for cooling the bearings, pumps and machineries. The discharge from various operations contain some oil and other waste materials. At present, the water is being discharged with ash. Eventually, this water goes to the river through a canal. Since there is no wastewater treatment facility at the site, the oil from the water should be skimmed off
 Annex 4.7 121 before discharging with ash in order to prevent the oil from contaminating the canal and the river. The skimmed oil should be disposed properly. There may be a need to have a small incinerator at the site to burn oily wastes in order to protect the environment. All waste water is discharged by mixing with ash and later it is used for irrigation and then discharge to the river. There is enough room at the ash pond site to install a waste water treatment facility if it is required after conducting a thorough analysis of wastewater discharges. 6. Impact of High Ash Content in Coal The coal/oil-fired boilers are equipped with electrostatic precipitators to remove ash up to 98 to 99 percent. To minimize ash content in flue gas, the boilers are supplemented with about ten to thirty percent natural gas. Opacity meter in each duct work is recommended to determine the level of dust concentration emitting into the atmosphere. There is a need for dispersion models to determine the concentrations levels of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust in the surrounding areas. Ash is being mixed with water and pumped to about eight kilometers to the ash pond, where ash is settled and water is directed to the canal. Water from the canal is being used for irrigation and the remaining water goes to the river. The bank has requested a detailed analysis of wastewater, coal and ash. Normally, ash contains a number of hazardous compounds such as arsenic, mercury, chromium, nickel, copper, uranium and other radioactive materials. Detailed analysis will determine the course of action needed to protect the environment, health and safety of the people. 7. Boiler Inefficiency After visual inspection of the ash color at the pond, it appears there is a significant amount of unburnt carbon left with ash. The reason for unburnt carbon is due to poor pulverization of coal. The plant engineers have requested the management to provide new ball mills so that the coal can be pulverized into fine particles for improved combustion. Due to lack of funds, the idea of installing the ball mills has been dropped. Probably a single ball mill installed in the main coal feeder line before the hammer mills may be a cost effective approach to improve the combustion efficiency. It will have some impact on emissions reduction due to less amount of coal being used in the boilers. Further study is required on this subject. Currently, hammer mills are having a high maintenance and the breakdowns are frequent in the power plant. Coal/oil/gas-fired boilers are equipped with low NOx burners, which will reduce NOx formation. Coal and heavy oil contain a high amount of sulfur which are contributing towards high emissions of sulfur dioxides. There is no sulfur removal technology installed at the plant. However, when all ducts are connected to a single tall chimney having a height of 300 meters, the impact of sulfur dioxides emissions on the population will be reduced due to improved dispersion of sulfur dioxides particles. It will minimize health impact to the surrounding population. 8. Analytical Requirements The chemical laboratory of the power plant is not well equipped. The laboratory provides a routine water analysis of PH, BOD, phosphate, sulfate, nitrate etc. They do not have equipment to measure metal contents in water and radioactive content of the ash. At a minimum, the laboratory needs a chromatograph, spectrophotometer, mass spectrograph, and equipment for measuring particle size distribution of ash, ultimate and proximate analysis of coal etc. A minimum amount of 150,000 dollars is requested under the environmental management plan for conducting various key analysis in the power plant on a regular basis. It will not only improve the environment but will also help in improving the process operation.
 122 Annex 4.7 9. Ash Disposal Site Ash is flying throughout the ash disposal facility due to high activity of bulldozers and other ash moving equipment. The ash disposal site contains about nine million tons of ash. At present, about 100,000 tons of ash is being sold to brick and cement industries. The total ash generated is in the range of about 600,000 tons per year. It is suggested that if the ash is given away free, a number of users can be attracted to take away ash and the disposal problems will be more manageable. There are several hundred houses located adjacent to the ash pond. Although we understand that the people have illegally built the houses very close to the pond, but there is a need to protect the welfare and health of the people. One way to protect the ash flying in the housing development is to built a retaining wall of about ten feet high followed by the trees planted in front of the wall. This can prevent the dust going in to the community. Initially, we reconmmend that the power company KNEHC should only plant the trees between the canal and the conmmunity in order to protect the people from ash inhalation and if the trees do not provide enough protection then the retaining wall should be considered. At the ash disposal site, a considerable amount of municipal and other power plant garbage is being dumped on both sides of the road. There is a need to straighten out the dumps and the grass should be planted on each side of road slopes. Furthermore, a water sprinkler systems to cover the entire area of ash pond would be desired to minimize the disturbance of the dust into the atmosphere. I. DISTRICT HEATING 10. Corrosion Control The district heating lines are not protected from internal and external Corrosion. Most of the district heating pipes are of schedule 40 to 80 pipes. Some of the old lines (about 25 years old) have been corroded and need replacement. In this project, about seventeen kilometers corroded lines will be replaced. There is a need to look at using the sacrificial or impressed current systems particularly for those pipelines which are buried underground without any corrosion protection. Most of the underground pipelines are installed in cement vault, where external corrosion problems will not be significant. However, internal corrosion will remain a major problem and further investigation is needed to improve deareation system or use of chemical protection system that will not harm the people using hot water for domestic need. 11. Asbestos Most of the District heating and steam pipes are laid in underground concrete channel. At times, the water is leaked through the cracks of concrete elements creating a problem of soaked insulation which leads to high heat losses. This problem can be minimized by installing capacitance or resistance probes with alarms at various locations, which can indicates the location of water leaks in the concrete channel. This will allow to repair the leak within a short time in order to minimize heat losses. The metal casing of the pipes are removed by the inhabitants leaving the insulation unprotected on the pipes. The power company has provided the asbestos casing which has created an environmental hazard. Asbestos casing for underground pipes will not have much impact on the environment. There are twenty kilometers of above ground pipes that are coated with asbestos. Asbestos from above ground pipes will normally disburse into the atmosphere quickly. However, there is a need to protect the environment by replacing the asbestos coating for the above ground pipes with either a coat of mazut or a layer of cement mixed with straw to protect it from cracking.
 Annex 4.7 123 III. Power Transmission And Distribution Reinforcement 12. PCB The rehabilitation of substations will include changing of old transformers, relays and other components. The consultant on transmission component, American Electric Power Company, has taken a few samples of the transformer oil to analyze for PCB in the United States. The analysis did not find any PCB in the oil samples and, therefore, a PCB replacement program would not be required. 13. Ala-Archa Substation A new Ala-Archa Substation will be installed to provide a third independent bulk power supply source to the city of Bishkek to improve its power supply reliability. The mission has visited the site of the new substation and the right of way for the transmission lines and did not find that there would not be any adverse impact on the environment. The transmission lines (20 km of a 220-kV double circuit line) are passing through the mountains and flat land where the nearest town is about three kilometers away. From the environmental point of view, the mission does not envisage any problem constructing the transmission lines as shown in the drawing. 14. Erosion There was no erosion observed on the slopes near the substations and transmission lines. Ground cover is properly maintained. 15. Flora and Fauna The impact of flora and fauna appears to be minimal. 16. No herbicides are being used to the grass. The maintenance at substations and underneath the transmission lines are conducted manually. The new transmission lines will pass through agriculture and the mountainous areas, where disturbance to vegetation would be minimal. Temporary impacts will occur during construction but with proper revegetation erosion could be minimized. There are no houses located in the right of way of transmission lines. Post construction maintenance will occur only in a few vegetated areas impacted during construction and will not create much disturbance to the environment. 17. Land use impacts are minimized because the new lines will not pass through any housing development or animal habitat. There will not be any potential health effects from electric and magnetic fields because the transmission will not pass through any residential areas. 18. Contamination of soils under the existing equipment was observed at two sub- stations where old transformers and capacitors are being replaced. There is a need to scoop out the contaminated soil to prevent the oil penetrating into the ground water. In addition, steps should be taken to minimize potential contamination. IV. INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY BUILDING 19. In order to successfully implement the Environmental Management Plan, a proper training in environmental monitoring, ensuring compliance requirements, review of design studies to ensure environmental protection requirements, and to follow implementation plan would be essential to protect the environment.
 124 Annex 4.7 V. IMPLEMENTATION FOLLOW-UP 20. Implementation of the Environmental Management Plan should commence immediately after loan approval. Environmental considerations identified in this report should be followed. Schedule and milestones for all major activities should be developed. VI. MONITORING AND REPORTING 21. There is a need for monitoring prior to, during, and after completion of the construction. Monitoring the implementation of environmental management recommendations should be reported to the Hank in accordance with the loan requirements. Environmental monitoring should be reported every quarter during the construction and even for one year after the facilities are operating.

The goal of environmental management plan is not only to reduce environmental degradation from the operations of the power plant and district heating systems but also to minimize the health and safety impacts on the workers and also to develop a program of continuous environmental improvement in all its activities. Specific key mitigation measures for the proposed action are the following: strengthen and maintain an environmental management system as a means of ensuring that the effects of the operations of the organization conform to its environmental policy, objectives and targets, and define responsibility for ensuring that the environmental requirements be implemented and maintained; and define and document the responsibility, authority and interrelations of key personnel who manage, perform, and verify work affecting the environment.  STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT KYRGYZ REPUBLIC KYRGYZSTAN NATIONAL ENERGY HOLDING COMPANY (KNEHC) ANNEX 5.2 AssuMPTIONS UNDERLYING THE FINANCIAL PROJECTIONS A. GENERAL 1. This document spells out the main assumptions made in the financial model of KNEHC (March 1996 version). 2. The financial projections were prepared in Soms. Domestic inflation was assumed to evolve as follows: Assumed Domestic Inflation Rates 1995 1996 1997 1998 1999 2000 28.70% 15.00% 9.00% 4.10% 2.60% 2.60% It was assumed that in future years, the exchange rate of the Som would remain constant at Som 11.0 = US$1.00 (December 31, 1994 exchange rate is Som 10.65 = US$ 1.00). 3. KNEHC's maintains its books in accordance with regulations issued annually by the Ministry of Finance. When the differences are material, certain accounts were restated to conform with International Accounting Standards;' nevertheless, significant differences may remain. KNEHC's accounts will be audited by recognized auditors, at which time more meaningful data will be developed. The forecast, on the other hand, reflects international accounting principles. B. INCOME STATEMENTS 4. Operating Statements for Electricity and District Heating appear at Appendix 1. a. Electricity 5. Revenues from electricity sales were derived from the Sales Forecast (in GWh), the forecast of revenues per kWh in tyin, and the itemized calculation of revenues at Appendix 2. One should note the following with respect to energy sales: (i) for the domestic market, the sales forecast is based on KNEHC data revised by the mission; In particular, accounts receivable are understated in KNEHC's books; overdue debt service charges remain part of long term debt; and income is recognized when payment has been received.
 142 Annex 5.2 (ii) for the export market, it is assumed that, in line with the agreement concluded for 1995, Kazakhstan will import annually 1,500 GWh at an average tariff of US04.0/kWh (excluding a 20% VAT); (iii) the average revenues per kWh sold in the domestic market reflect the present tariffs and increases whose magnitude appear at the bottom of the table; (iv) revenues from energy exports to China at 10 kV are at the fixed rate of 0.14 yuan/kWh. It was assumed that the yuan will decline by 10% a year against the Som. Exports to China at 220 kV, for which an export contract is yet to be finalized, were assumed to be priced at US3/kWh. Regarding exports of regulation services, and spinning reserves, these were assumed to increase from their 1994 level in accordance with inflation. 6. The forecast of electricity generation appears at Appendix 3. It is based on KNEHC data which was revised by the mission. One should note that "unaccounted for electricity" increases steadily from 11% of generation in 1991 to 23% in 1995, and declines in subsequent years. 7. In order to calculate the cost of fuels required for thermal power generation at Bishkek and Osh (both being CHP plants), the mission assumed the heat rates at Appendix 4 (expressed in g of coal at 4,000 kcal/kg). It was also assumed that the fuel mix in Bishkek would remain stable at the 1995 level (coal - 65%, natural gas - 20%, fuel oil - 15%), and similarly that at Osh it would remain at the level of 72% fuel oil and 28% natural gas. It was further assumed that I ton of coal would be equivalent to 475 MCM of natural gas, and to 0.4 ton of fuel oil. The calculation of fuel oil and coal quantities attributed to power generation appears at Appendix 4. The prices offuels, based on KNEHC data, appear at Appendix 5. These were assumed to remain constant, in US$ terms, at mid-1995 level throughout the forecast period. The total (i.e. electric power and district heating) forecast consumption of fossil fuels appears at Appendix 5, and their overall cost at Appendix 6. 8. It was assumed that imports of electricity ceased in 1995. 9. Operation and Maintenance (O&M) expenses, Salaries and Wages, General and Administrative (G&A) expenses and Other Expenses, were all assumed to increase in accordance with inflation. 10. No separate forecasts were made for the depreciation of electricity and district heating assets as no breakdown of fixed assets by category was available. b. District IIeating 11. The detailed forecast of heat sales, of the heat tariffs and of heat revenues appear at Appendix 7. Assumptions regarding tariff adjustments are at the bottom of the table.
 Annex 5.2 143 12. The forecast of heat production appears at Appendix 7. It is based on KNEHC data. In order to calculate the volume of fuels required for heat production at Bishkek and Osh (both being CHP plants), the mission calculated the heat rates at Appendix 4. The prices of fels, based on KNEHC data, appear at Appendix 5. These were assumed to remain constant, in US$ terms, throughout the forecast period. The total (i.e. electric power and district heating) forecast cost offossilfuels appears at Appendix 6. 13. Operation and Maintenance (O&M) expenses, Salaries and Wages and General and Administrative (G&A) expenses were forecast to grow at the same pace as inflation. C. Consolidated Income Statements 14. The consolidated Income Statements include additional provisions for other revenues, non- allocated expenses, depreciation, interest and income tax. 15. Regarding other revenues and non-allocated expenses, these originate from the sale of cement and hot water to industry and their corresponding costs. It was assumed that these will increase in accordance with inflation. 16. Depreciation rates in effect for the main categories of assets are as follows: Depreciation Rates in Effect Dams 1.0% Transmission Lines (35-220 kV) Metal Poles 2.0% Wood Poles 3.3% Transmission Lines (4-20 kV) Metal Poles 3.0% Treated Wood Poles 4.0% Untreated Wood Poles 6.0% Transformers 4.4% Distribution Lines 4.0% Vehicles 14.3% It was assumed for the time being that the depreciation rates would be equivalent to 3% of the average fixed assets in operation (the fixed assets in operation appear on the Balance Sheets). 17. The interest expense was derived from the Debt Schedule at Appendix 8. 18. KNEHC is subject to Income Tax as follows: (i) a 0.8% tax on revenues billed; (ii) a 1.5% tax on the increase in accounts receivable; and (iii) a 30% tax on gross income from which
 144 Annex 5.2 the first two are deductible2. The model assumes that KNEHC pays income tax at the higher of 0.8% of revenues, and 30% of operating income less interest3. C. BALANCE SHEETS 19. Cash was calculated on a residual basis. 20. Accounts Receivable were calculated in terms of days of sale equivalent (see assumption on bottom of Balance Sheets). 21. Stocks were assumed to increase in accordance with the inflation from 1994 onwards. 22. Additions to FixedAssets were derived from the Investment Program (Appendix 9). It was assumed that all investments, except for major generation schemes and transmission lines would be put into service the year the investments are incurred. 23. Additions to Work in Progress reflect essentially the 1993 balance, and major investments (generation and transmission lines) as they appear in the Investment Program at Appendix 9. 24. Other Assets were assumed to remain constant throughout the forecast period. 25. Short term borrowings were calculated on a residual basis. 26. Accounts Payable include mostly fossil fuels, but also debts to contractors, and workers involved in dams construction. They were assumed to be equivalent to accounts receivable. 27. The Long Term Debt was derived from the Debt Schedule (Appendix 8). It was assumed that KNEHC would be able to finance 70% of its investment program through external borrowings (which appear as "Future Loans"). D. SOURCES AND APPLICATIONS OF FUNDS 28. The Sources and Applications of Funds Statements were derived from the Income Statements and Balance Sheets above. The investment program is at Appendix 9. 2 To the extent that KNEHC's assets are not revalued appropriately, the depreciation allowance is understated, so that this tax penalizes the utility correspondingly. 3 In fact, income tax is based on the actual revenues reduced by the pro-rata share of expenses. This is unjust, given that KNEHC operates in a highly inflationary environment, and that much of its receivables are of a doubtful quality.

 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT KYRGYZ REPUBLIC POWER AND DISTRICT HEATING REHABILITATION PROJECT ANNEX 6.1 BISHKEK CHP PLANT AND DISTRICT HEATING SYSTEM PROJEcT ECONOMIC ANALYSIS A. METHODOLOGY 1. As the Bishkek CHP plant concurrently serves electric, district heating and process steam requirements in Bishkek and surrounding areas, the project preparation consultants developed an economic model during the feasibility study to simulate system operation. The model projected future system operating costs based on dispatching of electric and thermal supply resources to concurrently serve power, heat and steam loads while minimizing total energy (fuel and power from the grid) costs. The time horizon for the study was 1995-2005 to enable the model to capture the effects of the proposed capital investments and load growth to 2005; the analysis was extended to 2014 using a frozen load methodology to enable end effects to be captured without obscuring the analysis with the effects of longer term load growth and resulting capacity requirements. The model also examined the adequacy of production resources to meet future loads and added new electric/thermal capacity if necessary (criteria for adding new capacity: 15% reserve margin or largest unit out, whichever was more stringent). 2. Four base cases were run using the model: (a) do nothing, except add new capacity if needed; (b) Bishkek CHP plant rehabilitation; (c) Bishkek district heating system rehabilitation and modernization which also allowed integration of the local DH system into the Bishkek DH system; and (d) Bishkek CHP plant and DH system rehabilitation, i.e., cases (b) and (c) above combined. These cases were then re-run assuming expansion of the market in the areas served by the local DH system, as these are newly developing parts of the city which are expected to grow over the near-medium term. Under both scenarios, the combined rehabilitation of the Bishkek CHP plant and DH system had the lowest net present value of costs (capital, energy and O&M); rehabilitation of the Bishkek CHP plant alone and of the Bishkek DH system alone were also lower cost than the do nothing/without project alternative. 3. In using the results of the preparation consultants' model to calculate the economic internal rate of return of the individual project components and the two components combined, some adjustment in the operation of the model was necessary. In those cases where there was no rehabilitation of the CHP plant, the model added new generating capacity (a new 90 MW steam turbine, at a cost of about US$ 21 million installed); in the cases with rehabilitation of the CHP plant, no new capacity was needed. Similarly in those cases where there was no rehabilitation of the DH system, and hence no integration of the local DH system into the Bishkek DH system, the model added new heat production capacity for the local system (a 50 Gcal/hr heat-only boiler, at a cost of about US$ 1.2 million); in the cases with rehabilitation of the Bishkek DH system, no new capacity was needed. Under all cases above, there would be sufficient capacity, allowing for retirements, to meet electric and thermal demand through 2014, the period considered in the analysis. 4. In calculating the EIRRs for the project, it is necessary to isolate the benefits which are directly attributable to the project. For this, the preparation consultants re-ran the four cases assuming no capital investments (other than project investments), but taking into consideration expected retirements. In the cases of no CHP rehabilitation, installed capacity would fall below peak power demand in 2009, while in the cases of no DH rehabilitation, installed capacity in the local DH system would fall below peak heat demand in 2005; there would be no shortfall in meeting demand in the rehabilitation cases. Based on the load duration curves, rough estimates were made of the unserved electric and thermal energy demand in
 146 Annex 6.1 the no rehabilitation cases. Project benefits were then calculated as the difference between the energy and O&M costs with and without rehabilitation, plus the incremental sales valued at an estimated willingness to pay. Except for the incremental cost of transmitting and distributing the additional electric sales, production costs of the incremental demand served in the with rehabilitation cases are already included in terms of reducing the energy and O&M cost savings. It should be noted that this estimate of unserved demand is very conservative, as it considers only the shortfall between peak demand and installed capacity for the period of the peak without considering planned/forced outages. 5. The preparation consultants' model also has some other shortcomings which tend to make it conservative in terms of estimating project benefits. First, the model is considering only part of the power system serving the country--that which serves Bishkek and surrounding areas. Bishkek is presently able to import up to 200 MW additional capacity from the grid and export a similar amount. The Bishkek CHP plant is mainly used in the winter when power demand is the highest, supply from the country's hydro resources is restricted and there is a need for heat in Bishkek. Hydro constraints are not considered in the model, which may lead to some underutilization of the Bishkek CHP plant and hence underestimation of project benefits. Second, the model does not take into consideration that optimal dispatching of district heat is now constrained by system operating conditions; introduction of variable flow under the project will enable improved load dispatching using the HOBs as peak load units. Hence, the cost savings due to the difference in HOB use in the with and without DH rehabilitation cases may be understated. This said, the model provides a reasonable simulation of the operation of a complex system, for use in estimating project benefits. The main assumptions are given below, followed by the results of the EIRR and sensitivity analyses carried out during project appraisal. Full details of the model are in the feasibility study in the project file. B. MAIN AssuMprIONS 6. Investment Costs. Investment costs are the baseline project costs of the Bishkek CHP plant and DH system rehabilitation components in 1995 constant prices and exchange rate'' plus an allowance for implementation assistance (about 2.2%) and physical contingencies (about 10%); project costs are net of customs duties and taxes. Expenditures are spread over 1996-99, the expected implementation period of the project components. Project costs are given in detail in Annex 4.8. 7. Production Costs. O&M and energy costs for all electric and thermal generating plants (Bishkek CHP plant, Bishkek DH system HOBs, local DH system HOBs) and for the district heating and process steam distribution systems (Bishkek and local DH system) are incorporated in the preparation consultants' economic model. O&M costs include labor, materials and consumables. These have been estimated based on the current practices and operating experience of the utility and the expected savings resulting from rehabilitation and modernization under the project. All costs are in 1995 constant prices. 8. Energy costs include fuel and power from the grid. For fuels, unit costs are based on the current import prices including transport and excluding duties and taxes; these are: coal US$ 37/ton (US$ 8.8/Gcal), natural gas US$ 77/1000 cubic meters (US$ 9.4/Gcal) and fuel oil US$ 100/ton (US$ 10.5/Gcal). The Bishkek CHP plant mainly uses coal and lesser amounts of gas and oil, while the HOBs use gas; the model results are not sensitive to fuel prices because the main benefit of the rehabilitation is reduction in fuel use (rather than switching among fuels). Fuel efficiency and consumption parameters 1/ Project costs have been estimated assuming a constant nomimal exchange rate; since domestic inflation is expected to be somewhat higher than international inflation for the next couple of years, the exchange rate would appreciate in real terms. Given the small amount of local costs in the project (about 17%) and uncertainty about the amount of real appreciation in the exchange rate, the economic analysis has been done in constant 1995 dollars without taking the real appreciation into consideration. However, project EIRRs are sensitivity tested with increased investment costs and remain acceptable.
 Annex 6.1 147 are based on the current practices and operating experience of the utility and the expected changes in performance resulting from rehabilitation and modernization under the project. The price of power from the grid is based on current electricity export prices, or 3.0 UScents/kWh; a maximum of 200 MW is assumed available to Bishkek (based on transmission capacity). This is used in optimizing load dispatching and affects the amount of GWh generated by the Bishkek CHP plant; annual power generation of the plant projected by the model is line with (or somewhat below) that expected to be required, based on past experience and availability of alternative sources of supply (mainly hydro). 9. The incremental production cost of serving the incremental demand in the rehabilitation cases is mostly included in the reduced energy and O&M savings in the with rehabilitation cases relative to the without rehabilitation cases. For heat in fact, all costs can be considered to be included since heat production and distribution costs are included in the economic model. For power, an additional cost needs to be included for transmission and distribution; this is estimated as 20% of the long-run cost of generation (3.7 UScents/kWh, see para. 5, Annex 6.2), or 0.7 UScents/kWh. 10. Demand. Power and heat (district heating, hot water and process steam) sales forecasts for the Kyrgyz Republic are given in Annex 2.5. These are somewhat below estimates in the Bank's Energy Sector Review in line with the Bank's current macro projections for the country; they also take into consideration data for the first six months of 1995. For power, growth in sales is forecast to average about 3% p.a. through 2005; faced with increasing power tariffs and a reversal of the Government's policy of encouraging use of electrical resistance heating, it is expected that growth in residential consumption will slow, while non-residential consumption will gradually increase in line with the country's economic recovery. For heat, sales are expected to remain low for 1995 due to continued rationing by KNEHC to conserve imported fuels, but should increase in 1996-97 to levels closer to historical consumption but lower because some consumers will have switched to electrical heating and because of increased attention on the part of KNEHC and the consumers to conservation. Over the longer term, assuming the project goes ahead, it is expected that heat sales will remain relatively constant, with sales to new consumers offset by improved system controls on heat supply (introduction of variable flow) and reduced consumer wastage; reduction in network losses will further reduce the required heat production to supply these sales. 11. Forecasts used in the economic model are for the Bishkek area and are consistent with the above forecasts. In the case of power, the demand forecast is the same for the with and without Bishkek CHP plant rehabilitation cases. In the case of district heating, the demand forecast for the without Bishkek DH system rehabilitation case is slightly higher than that for the with rehabilitation case because of the impact of the rehabilitation and modernization works on efficiency of heat supply. The demand forecasts are used in the economic model to calculate the production costs with and without rehabilitation, the difference being the cost savings due to the project, and the estimated amount of incremental demand served in the rehabilitation cases (para. 4). The forecasts are considered conservative. 12. Willingness to Pay Valuation. Willingness to pay estimates are needed for valuing the incremental power and heat demand which will be served in the with rehabilitation cases. Given the lack of data for the key parameters needed to define such estimates, a simple approach has been followed. In the case of power, the main alternative to electricity for residential consumers is kerosene lighting (29 UScents/kWh) and for non-residential consumers self-generation from captive diesel plants (13 UScents/kWh). Using these figures and the current tariff (0.82 UScents/kWh for residential and 1.64 UScents/kWh for non-residential consumers), a 0.33 demand curve demand curve coefficient, and 40:60 mix of residential and non-residential consumers, the estimated WTP for power is 4.7 UScents/kWh, or about four times the current tariff. A similar analysis was done for heat, where in urban areas the main

Since the current non-residential heat tariff is about the same cost as alternative heat sources, the current tariff was used as a proxy for the non-residential WTP in deriving an overall WTP; this results in an estimated WTP for heat of US$ 15.7/Gcal, or about 1.3 times the current tariff.
