 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT KYRGYZ REPUBLIC POWER AND DISTRICT HEATING REHABILITATION PROJECT ANNEx 6.2 TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION FACILITIES PROJECT ECONOMIC ANALYSIS A. METHODOLOGY 1. During the feasibility study, the project preparation consultants developed load flow models for the transmission and distribution systems serving the Bishkek area and a representative rural area (Kalinin under the Chu Electric Company) to assist in identifying system needs, evaluating alternative reinforcement schemes, and prioritizing investment alternatives. To the extent possible, these results were extrapolated to assess the overall situation of the country's T&D system. In addition, at KNEHC's request, a supplemental study financed by the Swiss government carried out a detailed evaluation of the 220-kV interconnection between Kemin and Naryn. Based on these analyses and taking into consideration budget limitations under the project, the consultants together with their counterparts in KNEHC selected the least cost, highest priority T&D components for inclusion in the project. These include: (a) construction of the 220/1 10-kV Ala Archa substation in the outskirts of Bishkek to relieve overloaded lines/transformers at Glavnaia substation and provide a second transmission source to the city; (b) construction of the 220/1 10-kV Naryn substation to complement completion of the 220-kV transmission line interconnecting Kemin and Naryn (financed separately by EBRD) and to relieve overloaded lines/transformers and significantly improve power supply to Kumtor gold mine and the Issyk-Kul and Naryn regions; (c) installation of replacement or additional transformers in five substations (of various voltages) to relieve system overloading; (d) installation of circuit breakers and associated improved relay protection in twelve substations to improve system protection; and (e) provision of meters and other essential tools. The full list of priority investments for northern Kyrgyz Republic, prepared during the feasibility study, is attached as Table 1. 2. Project benefits for the individual T&D components were quantified based on the results of the load flow simulation studies and system operating experience. Benefits quantified in the analysis include: (a) reduced energy losses valued at the long-run cost of generation; (b) deferred generating capacity additions (resulting from reduced system losses) valued at the capital cost of new generating capacity; and (c) reduced frequency of outages valued at a conservatively estimated 20 UScents/kWh. While incremental sales (resulting from increased transmission capacity due to new and replaced transformers) have been quantified and are a significant project benefit, they have not been included in the economic analysis due to uncertainty in the demand forecasts and the low WTP due to the low current level of tariffs (if included, they would be valued at the WTP less the long-run cost of supply); this results in a conservative estimate of the potential project benefits. The time horizon for the study was 1995-2024, or 25 years after completion of the T&D rehabilitation and reinforcement work. Further details are included in the project feasibility study and supplemental report (Kemin-Naryn interconnection) in the project file; the main assumptions and results of the EIRR and sensitivity analyses carried out during appraisal are given below. B. MAIN ASSUMPTIONS 3. Investment and O&M Costs. Investment costs are the baseline project costs of the individual
 Annex 6.2 153 T&D components in 1995 constant prices and exchange rate'' plus an allowance for implementation assistance (about 2.2%) and physical contingencies (about 10%); project costs are net of customs duties and taxes. Expenditures are spread over 1996-99, the expected implementation period of the T&D component. Project costs are given in detail in Annex 4.8. In the case of the Naryn substation, an additional US$ 6.0 million is included in the investment costs in 1996 to account for the EBRD-financed works (completion of Kemin-Naryn 220-kV transmission line, provision of 220-kV bay at Kemin and construction of provisional 220/1 10-kV substation at Naryn); these works are expected to be commissioned by end-1996 (in time to supply the Kumtor gold mine), and the permanent 220/1 10-kV substation at Naryn (being financed under the present project and using all recoverable equipment from the provisional substation) is expected to be commissioned in 1999. Incremental O&M costs associated with the T&D component have been included in the analysis at I % of investment costs. 4. Demand. As indicated in Annex 6.1 (para. 10), a power sales forecast for the Kyrgyz Republic is given in Annex 2.5. The forecast used in the load flow studies and quantification of project benefits for the T&D component is consistent with this forecast, where growth in sales is projected at about 3% p.a. and growth in peak demand at 2-2.5% p.a. Important underlying assumptions to the forecast, in terms of its impact on T&D system requirements, are that fuel would be available to operate the Bishkek CHP plant (supplies have been restricted in recent years due to high import prices) and there would be no further increase in electrical heating. If this is not the case, increased overloading of the T&D system would be expected, with a risk of system collapse; at the same time, loss reduction and reduced outage benefits from the project would increase. 5. Power Supply Costs. Power supply costs are needed for valuing the loss reduction benefits of the project in energy terms; the capital cost of new generating capacity is needed for valuing the loss reduction benefits in capacity terms. Assuming a continuing mix of 85:15 hydro and thermal generation in the Kyrgyz system, the average cost of new generation is estimated at 3.7 UScents/kWh (3.7 UScents/kWh for new hydro capacity based on the US$ 900/kW capital cost estimate for the next hydro project; 3.6 UScents/kWh for new gas-fired CHP capacity installed at the TES 2 plant in Bishkek (presently only HOB capacity) at an estimated cost of US$ 600/kW). In the economic analysis, 3.7 UScents/kWh is used to value the loss reduction benefits in energy terms. US$ 750/kW is used to value the loss reduction benefits in capacity terms; to meet domestic needs, new capacity is not expected to be needed before 2005 or so. 6. Power Outage Costs. The addition of the Ala Archa and Naryn substations and installation of improved system protection in twelve substations under the project are expected to result in reduced frequency of power outages. In the case of the Ala Archa and Naryn substations, reduced outage estimates are based on historical statistics for forced and planned outages in the Bishkek and Naryn areas provided by KNEHC; in the case of the twelve substations, a conservative forced outage rate of 10% per year has been assumed for the 110-kV/low voltage transformers. The economic cost of outages can be very high because they disrupt all types of activities and can damage equipment. A conservative figure of 20 UScents/kWh has been used in the economic analysis to value the reduction in outages attributable to the project. This might be compared with the cost of owning and operating a stand-by diesel generator for use in the event of an outage; assuming 200 hours of outages per year, the cost would be 66 UScents/kWh. While many consumers would not have stand-by generators, using an economic cost of 20 UScents/kWh can be considered a low estimate of the benefit. I/ Project costs have been estimated assuming a constant nominal exchange rate; since domestic inflation is expected to be somewhat higher than international inflation for the next couple of years, the exchange rate would appreciate in real terms. Given the small amount of local costs in the project (about 17%) and uncertainty about the amount of real appreciation in the exchange rate, the economic analysis has been done in constant 1995 dollars without taking the real appreciation into consideration. However, project EIRRs are sensitivity tested with increased investment costs and remain acceptable.

doc.repnme: Kyrgyz Republic - Power and District Heating Rehabilitation Project
doc.abstracts: The main objectives of the Power and District Heating Rehabilitation Project are to support economic growth through rehabilitation and upgrading of the electricity and heat supply infrastructure and to assist the government in restructuring the power and district heating sector. Specific objectives are to: 1) improve the power and district heating system efficiency and reliability; 2) reduce power and heat losses; 3) reduce the environmental impact of the power and heat facilities; 4) rehabilitate the existing assets in the power and district heating system; 5) introduce appropriate financial management at Kyrgyz National Energy Holding Company (KNEHC); 6) restructure KNEHC along commercial lines; and 7) attract private sector interest in petroleum exploration and production. The project will finance priority investments in the energy sector. Its components include: 1) for KNEHC: (a) rehabilitation of the Bishkek combined-heat-and-power plant; (b) district heating system rehabilitation; (c) rehabilitation and upgrading of power transmission and distribution facilities; and (d) technical support and training; and 2) for the government: provision of consultant services and training for petroleum exploration promotion.
